This is one of my favorite "home front" photos of WWII.  It is from a series of color photos showing home front industry, railroads, and agriculture taken during the war.  The Black woman looks pretty, strong, and determined.  In the same series of photos, there is a pretty white girl soldering electronic circuits and an older white woman working in a railroad yard.  All of them were serious in building or moving war material so their husbands, boyfriends, sons, fathers, and brothers would be supplied with the stuff to enable them to win and make it home alive.  British and Russian women worked even longer hours for the same reason, but the Nazis were very slow in employing women in their war industries because they had outdated ideas about "a woman's place."  The slave labor the Nazis used didn't care and actively sabotaged things when they could get away with it.  Women like this one played a major part in wining WWII.

From: Maidremm@cs.com 
Subject: Pat Connolly 1917 World Class Wrestler 
Date: Fri, 5 Jul 2002 06:08:28 EDT 

" Hello listers,

I am trying to find any and all information about Pat Connolly. He was born in Co. Galway Ireland, and wrestled in Butte, Montana. He was listed in articles as a British Citizen. He wrestled Ed "Strangler" Lewis on December 3, 1916, and on either January 13, or January 15, 1917 Pat Connolly and Yussif Hussane battled to a 2 1/2 hour draw in Butte, Montana. This information was taken from The Wrestling Datebook, 1915 thru 1920. Pat also wrestled Ed"Strangler" Lewis on November 30, 1916 in Billings, Montana.

On January 15, 1917, Pat Connolly had a niece born in Boston, MA, and she was to be Christened on January 28, 1917. Pat traveled by railroad to the Christening, and somewhere between Butte and Boston he died on the way. Some say he was poisoned, some say shot, etc. It still remains a mystery.

I am hoping that someone may know of this man, or heard this story. Any help would be very much appreciated.

Thank you one and all, Mary "

I decided to do a bit of digging into the LOC photos posted here, as well as into some other materials, to see what I could find relating to the Bain News Service. This photo is a good start, because it shows us George Grantham Bain himself. You can see his signature in the bottom right hand corner of the document, which is from 1912. Here's a brief Wikipedia page about him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Grantham_Bain I should also mention this page that has information about the Bain collection: lcweb2.loc.gov/pp/ggbainhtml/ggbaintips.html It contains two GG Bain images that I couldn't find uploaded to Flickr: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.15074 (a photo of GGB undated) and hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.06606 (a caricature of GGB undated). Next, comes three photos that are a set: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163811426 www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163011685 www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163010885 They all show the same man (is he GGB? I don't think so) at the same machine. The first of the three shows the machine facing in a particular direction and also shows some menial peering out of a store room at the photographer. The second of the three shows the machine facing in a different direction and no menial. Someone has written across the top of the photo "Printing the Bain News Service photos" and has also written on the machine "Bain-McDonald auto-printer" (could the man in the photos be McDonald perhaps?). There's also an "X" placed over the store room area. The third of the three photos is the second photo again with bits blanked out. Next comes www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163507966 which is a 1910 subscription to GGB's service by a Canadian newspaper. Finally, there is www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163813254 which shows firemen on the roof of the Bain News Service Building in 1912, putting out a fire. (Was the building, perhaps, at the address shown in the preceding photo?)

interesting to see mr. bain, a new york photographer from chicago, getting a german driving license. I suspect he had to be fluent in german to get it.

the license isn't issued by an equivalent to the modern DMV (or KBA in germany) but the local Hamburg police. the stamp with the three turrets, similar to the official sign of the free city, is noteworthy as it has been in use since 1412 until today. I've only seen one other handwritten german document of the time and that's a german passport hanging in the visitor area of the german embassy in new york city. it's dated from a similar or possibly even earlier time and authorizes the document to a gentleman with the expressed purpose of travelling to the united states (aka "Amerika").

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/163482997@N06], The Library of Congress is not in a position to grant or deny permission to use images from the collections, because it doesn't own rights to the images. The images we put up in Flickr are those designated "No known restrictions on publication," which is the best we can say, meaning that the items have no donor restrictions and we know of no copyright restrictions on the items. However, privacy and publicity rights may apply. Users of the images, however, must assess the risks for their purposes, keeping in mind the types of restrictions that can come into play in addition to copyright and donor restrictions: privacy rights, publicity rights, licensing and trademarks. For more information about reproducing, publishing, and citing material from this collection, as well as access to the original items, see: www.loc.gov/rr/print/res/274_bain.html.

boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=52590&cat=boxer Although he is described as a Quaker by the Times, boxrec.com's biography says he was Jewish: "Name: Eddie O'Keefe Birth Name: Edward Paley Born: 1891-12-23 Died: 1963-09-00 (Age:71) Nationality: US American Hometown: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA Boxing Record: click O'Keefe was a brother of fellow boxer Barney Ford. O'Keefe was of Hebrew heritage, and was one of the many outstanding Hebrew fighters who came out of Philadelphia in the first half of the 20th century. He had over 100 fights in his career and defeated a number of world champions--e.g., Harry Forbes, Jackie "Kid" Wolfe, Johnny Dundee, "Kid" Williams, and featherweight title claimant Joe Coster. O'Keefe also defeated other outstanding fighters, including Hall of Famer Lew Tendler, Dutch Brandt, Johnny Solzberg, K O Eggers, Louisiana, and many others. Many of the Fight Record results were taken from the Philadelphia Record, courtesy of historian Chuck Hasson. Most of the other fight results taken from the Philadelphia Item. Regarded as one of the best bantamweights of all-time to come out of Philadelphia by phillyboxinghistory.com" See also:

Flynn, who had a reputation for fighting mean and dirty, met Heavyweight Champion Jack Johnson in the ring at Las Vegas, New Mexico, on July 4, 1912. Johnson had beaten Flynn in a non-title fight in 1907. Johnson hadn't trained for the rematch, but was still able to hold Flynn off for 14 rounds. Flynn, frustrated, engaged in obvious head-butting of his opponent, so the referee ended the fight and awarded victory to Johnson.

Could this photo and the other one have been taken at the Progressive Party ("Bull Moose") convention at the Coliseum in Chicago, in August, 1912? That convention was held in the same venue as the Republican Convention had been, in June. The date inscribed on the negative, in the lower right corner, appears to start with an "8" -- for August. A quarter of the delegates to the Progressives' convention were women (who were still denied the vote), and the convention nominated former President Theodore Roosevelt for President, and Governor Hiram Johnson of California for Vice President.

This is the second building with that name, and was located on Wabash Avenue, between 14th and 16th Streets until it was demolished in the 1980's. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Coliseum

The 1912 Progressive Party ("Bull Moose") Convention was held at this same venue in August. It nominated former President Teddy Roosevelt for President and Governor Hiram Johnson of California for Vice President. Woodrow Wilson, a Democrat, won the election in November.

The Google Maps marker for the Coliseum is incorrect.  It shows the Coliseum as between 16th and 18th Streets, but it was actually on the east side of Wabash between 14th and 16th Streets (per the Wikipedia article).  A Buddhist center called Soka Gakka International and its parking lots are now on the site.

Coliseum Park (which commemorates the Coliseum) is located acros the street on the southwest corner of 14th Place and Wabash.

1912 Republican National Convention

held at Chicago Coliseum
Chicago, Cook County, Illinois

resulting in the nomination of:

WILLIAM H. TAFT
for President

Accusations by Theodore Roosevelt of theft of Roosevelt delegates by the Taft cabal led to T.R.'s bolting the Republican Party and holding a Progressive Party ("Bull Moose") convention at this same venue in August. The split led to a fracturing of the vote in the November election which made Woodrow Wilson, the Democratic Party candidate, the winner.

(Candidate Sherman actually died before the election, and was replaced on the Republican ticket by Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University.)
The 1912 Progressive Party Convention, that nominated Teddy Roosevelt for President and Governor Hiram Johnson of California for Vice President, was held at the same venue, in August.

California's delegates may have been solid for Teddy Roosevelt (candidate for a non-consecutive third term) for the 1912 GOP nomination, but incumbent President William Howard Taft got the nod. Roosevelt, who had handpicked Taft as his successor but felt betrayed by the rightwing course Taft followed once in office, then bolted to the new Progressive Party, and became the "Bull Moose" candidate. The three-way split in the November election gave the win to Woodrow Wilson and the Democratic Party.

1912 Democratic Convention Baltimore, MD June 25 to July 2, 1912 Nominated:Woodrow Wilson of New Jersey for President Nominated: Thomas R Marshall of Indiana for Vice President In 1912 there were three major contenders for the Democratic nomination, The three were House Speaker Champ Clark,, Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee Congressman Oscar W Underwood and Woodrow Wilson governor of New Jersey. 1912 was the first year that the democrats had primaries to select delegates for the convention. Wilson and Clark each won a number of primaries, and Clark arrived at the convention with the largest number of delegates pledged to him. When the convention opened Clark received the support of the Tammany Organization in New York. That support had the effect of turning Byran who had been largely neutral into an opponent of Clarke. On the first ballot however, Clark led with 440 1/4 votes to 324 for Wilson, 148 for Harmon 117 1/4 for Underwood and the rest scattered. Ballots continued all evening. On the ninth ballot the New York delegation changed its vote to support Clark giving him a majority of the votes. In past conventions that would have been enough to begin a bandwagon for Clark, quickly giving him the 2/3 needed. Instead this time the opposition held their ground. Now once again Byran took center stage in a speech castigating Clark for being in the pocket privilege class. This solidified the anti Clark forces which centered on Wilson. Balloting continued for two days however, until on the 46th ballot Wilson acheived 2/3 of the votes and became the nominiee. www.multied.com/elections/Conventions/1912DEM.html

The Coliseum was located on Wabash Avenue between 14th and 16th Streets. It was the second Coliseum, and was built by Charles Gunther (candy factory owner) in 1899. 

Gunther had an entire Civil War prison (Libby Prison) dismantled and shipped by railroad car to Chicago to build the Coliseum. 

Today there is a park on the corner of Wabash and 14th called "Coliseum Park". The slabs in the park are parts of the original structure.

Miller abandoned his cabin home, and left Washington in 1885. In 1911, the cabin was threatened by development of its rustic site. The Capital's California delegation mounted a campaign to move the structure and preserve it. It was dismantled and reconstructed in Rock Creek Park, where it was dedicated in a public ceremony on June 12, 1912. Here's Wikipedia's version of the Miller Cabin story: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joaquin_Miller_Cabin

Miller died in 1913, a year after the cabin dedication ceremony (which he did not attend). His ashes were scattered near his home, "The Hights," in Oakland, California. New York Times story, May 26, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C07E1DC143FE6...

This is one of 4 Bain Collection photos of Jack Johnson taken in the same place and apparently at the same time, one of which is dated May 3, 1912

The date in the top right corner looks like March 1912.

If that's the case this photo could be part of the build up for the Fireman Jim Flynn fight that took place in Las Vegas that summer.  Johnson won that fight and again defended his hard won heavy weight title.

However, it was the last time he defended the title in the USA, fighting (and winning) twice in France before losing the crown to Jess Willard in Cuba in 1915. 

This photo could also be considered a mark of the end of Johnson's glory years.  After the Flynn fight he would be forced to move abroad to aviod arrest for various claimed crimes and wouldn't return to the US for 7 years.  His next fight in the US was in prison.

University of Michigan graduate Ralph Craig (1889-1972) won two gold medals as a sprinter at the 1912 Summer Olympics in Stockholm, Sweden. Wikipedia bio: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Craig
I have a restored and a colorized version of this photo: www.flickr.com/photos/buikhu/2379131165/

Here's some more Ralph Craig info from the Bentley Historical Library at the University of Michigan: bentley.umich.edu/athdept/olymp2/ol1912.htm The Stockholm games brought another Michigan double in the sprints, Ralph Craig winning both the 100 and 200 meter events. Craig had been the pre-Olympic favorite in the 100 meters until beaten by the unknown Howard Drew in the U.S. trials. A leg injury kept Drew from the Olympic finals. By one account there were eight false starts in the finals, three by Craig. In one of them Craig and another sprinter ran the entire distance. Apparently that was just a good warm-up for Craig. When there finally was a clean start, he won the race by two yards. Craig came back to lead a U.S. sweep of the 200 meters with a time just 1/10th of a second off Archie Hahn's Olympic record. Craig earned three letters in track at U of M, from 1909 to 1911. He never won a Big 10 title, however, as Michigan had withdrawn from the conference during those years. A very successful industrial engineer, Craig later won a spot as an alternate on the 1948 U.S. Olympic yachting team. bentley.umich.edu/athdept/olymp2/ol1948.htm Ralph Craig, double gold medal winner at Stockholm in1912, was an alternate on the yachting team. His team's boat "Rhythm" finished 11th in the dragon class. In recognition of his Olympic accomplishments, Craig was given the honor of carrying the U.S.flag in the opening ceremonies.

There's some info on the history of this ship here (scroll down) to mystery picture 74, to see a photo of it at sea. Mystery Picture #74 This is the cruiser Fei Hung, better known as the Greek Helle, running builder's sea trials. Fei Hung was one of a trio of small training cruisers ordered by the Chinese navy in 1910. The first of the class (Ying Swei) was completed in 1911 and delivered as scheduled, but the 1912 Chinese Revolution intervened before the remaining two ships, Chao Ho and Fei Hung, could be delivered. Both were placed up for sale, but were completed by their builders prior to being sold, probably in hope of attracting a buyer. Fei Hung was completed in 1913, and is seen here on trials, still owned by her builders, New York Shipbuilding. In 1914 she was sold to Greece and renamed Helle. Her sister Chao Ho did not find a buyer, and accepted by the Chinese navy, as originally intended. Helle had an interesting career. In 1916-1917 she served under the French flag, following the French seizure of the Greek fleet. She was completely reconstructed in 1926-1928, emerging as a cruiser-minelayer, with new machinery, superstructure, masts, and fire controls, modified armament, and increased armor. Helle was torpedoed and sunk by an Italian submarine, 15 August 1940, while at anchor off Tinos Island. This incident caused considerable anger, as Greece had not yet entered the war, and the Italian cruiser Eugenuio Di Savoia was provided postwar as a replacement for Helle.\

Also you can have a look in the Hellenic Navy page to see a photo of Helle in the interwar years as well as another image of the first torpedo that missed her in Tinos Island exploding on the dock. www.hellenicnavy.gr/ellh.asp

This trolley would most likely have run down Washington Street from Ashmont Station, across Gallivan Boulevard, and further down Washington Street to the Lower Mills neighborhood of Boston.  This neighborhood borders Milton, and is still the location of a commuter rail station where nearby Milton commuters catch the train into Boston.  Lower Mills was also home to the Baker Chocolate Company-- the buildings still stand but it has been made into condos.  Further, the triple (?)-decker  seen in the background may still stand-- multifamily houses are still the predominant form of housing stock in Dorchester.  Ashmont is still a terminus for one section of the current subway system.

Washington Street does not go near Ashmont Station, so it is perhaps more likely that the trolley would have run down Dorchester Avenue.  If the trolley also passed through Edward Everett Square, it would make sense that the trolley traveled along Dorchester Avenue rather than Washington Street.  The Milton Station car barn was located in Dorchester's Lower Mills near the bridge that crosses the Neponset River to Milton.

Earl Taylor, Dorchester Historical Society, Dorchester, MA

Sunday April 21, 1912, was a benefit exhibition game at the Polo Grounds between the Giants and the Yankees, still officially known as the Highlanders. The benefit was for the Titanic survivors who landed in New York that week. George M. Cohan performed and Broadway show girls "used their charm" to hawk raffle tickets through the stands. It was a lousy day so just over 14,000 attended with the Yanks and Jints, as well as the Polo Grounds staff. donating their labor. I think it is potentially the first National-American League match-up of New York ballclubs in the twentieth century. It certainly was the first professional baseball game in the City of New York on a Sunday (NY Times confirms this). This was during the years of the "blue laws" which prohibited just about everything on a Sunday. Admission was technically free and purchasing a program went to the charity. The Giants won 11-2 as Manager John McGraw (originally from Cortland County and hated to lose) used all his starters.

An excerpt from "The Great American Market" article in Housewives League Magazine published in November 1915; " WHILE the committee was at work it had been decided that as soon as the markets had been discovered a Market Day should be proclaimed; and that housewives should be asked to take their baskets and visit the most convenient one, while a delegation from the League should make a tour of them all. When it was discovered that there was only one public market in the city the proposed Market Day became a Washington Market Day. ... "The third of April was selected as the date for the great event. The Market was scrubbed and put into gala array for the occasion, and as there was no place for musicians on the floor a platform was built for them up under the roof. Each dealer also laid in a supply of market baskets, and every housewife who made a purchase received one to carry it home in. "As it was a new thing in those days for women to go to market the newspapers were delighted to give space to the story, and the following call to the housewives received wide publicity : "Wednesday, April 3, has been declared a public Market Day. "Please be at Washington Market between 10 and 12 A. M., to demonstrate to the City Fathers that the women of New York are in earnest in their demand for more public markets. The Washington Market Association is to welcome us. "Spread the news. "Secure all the recruits possible. "Two thousand women responded to this call, the Mayor and Superintendent of Markets also accepted invitations to be present, and the whole place swarmed with reporters and photographers. ... "Not only was Washington Market Day the event of the season locally, but the fame of it was spread abroad throughout the length and breadth of the land and became a large factor in the movement for public markets which has since swept the country. With the exception of the butter boycott, nothing that the League has ever done has attracted so much attention. All over the country women began to study the market question, and personal marketing became the fashion." www.archive.org/details/housewivesleague00housrich

The first skipper of the Queen Mary was Reginald "Blinker" Hall. He instituted a number of reforms designed to ease the life of the enlisted crew- including installing the first ships library in the Royal Navy. He later became the director of Naval Intelligence during WWI and is generally regarded as one of the best ever in that role. He supported, and made use of, the radio intercept intelligence produced by Room 40- as the High Seas Fleet found out to their sadness at Jutland.

The Hotel workers strike that grew to the Waiters strike: URGE CHAMBERMAIDS TO JOIN THE UNION; Rose Pastor Stokes and Other Speakers Appeal to Women Hotel Workers. June 9, 1912, Sunday The doors of Bryant Hall, in Sixth Avenue, below Forty-second Street, were thrown wide yesterday to admit the women hotel workers -- chambermaids, laundresses and scrubwomen -- who were summoned to a massmeeting designed to stir the spirit of unionism among them, whom, so far, it has not particularly moved. January 14, 1913, Tuesday Miss Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, the I.W.W. organizer, who was the principal speaker at a mass meeting of the International Hotel Workers' Union in Bryant Hall last night, took her audience by surprise by springing a proposal against tip-taking, and after considerable uproar and wrangling in four languages the final vote was unanimous against accepting gratuities if a living wage could be obtained from the hotel proprietors. The Carpathia actually arrived on the scene of the Titanic sinking on the morning of 15-April,1912.Titanic struck the berg at approximately 11:40 P.M. Mabel Choate (d. 1958)--daughter of Joseph Hodges Choate (1832-1917) and the former Caroline D. Sterling (1837-1929); her father was an attorney who served as US ambassador to England; her mother was one of the founders of Barnard College. The Riderless Horse (aka Caparisoned Horse) used during funeral processions of Army or Marine Corp colonels (or higher) or deceased presidents of the USA. The riderless horse bears the boots of the deceased (mounted backwards) as a symbol that the rider will never ride again. For more information: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riderless_horse www.arlingtoncemetery.net/caparisoned.htm usmilitary.about.com/od/jointservices/a/funeralhonors.htm

This would be the funeral of Maj. Gen. Frederick Dent Grant, U.S. Army, who died April 12, 1912, while commanding general of the Department of the East with headquarters at Governor's Island in New York Harbor.  General Grant was the son of Ulysses S. Grant.  There is a small collection of Frederick Dent Grant papers at Southern Illinois University, Carbondale, Illinois.

The elaborate 'costume' the horse is wearing is actually a knotted string 'fly sheet', designed to wick off sweat and keep the flies off the horse.  Also note that the boots are inserted backwards in the stirrups, which in most cases indicates the death of the rider.  Since Gen. F. D. Grant (son of Ullyses S.) died on April 12, 1912, this photo would have been taken a few days later at his funeral most likely.

I agree with XSPimages comments. This appears to be a caparisoned horse used during funeral processions to honor the deceased. The boots would be from Gen. Grant himself. The tradition can still be requested today for military personnel (colonel or above) who served in the Army or Marine Corp, or served as President of the USA. A caparisoned horse was used during Ronald Reagan's funeral. The horse bore the boots worn by Ronald Reagan and was escorted riderless down the procession in honor of the deceased president. More information: www.arlingtoncemetery.net/caparisoned.htm en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riderless_horse Too bad this image is fogged. This is a good looking animal.

Honus Wagner is considered by many to be baseball's greatest all-around player. The Pittsburgh Pirates' shortstop was a sensational hitter, a brilliant base-runner and a flawless fielder. He broke into the majors by hitting .344 in 1897 and put together 17 consecutive .300 seasons. He was the NL batting champion for seven of those 17 seasons with a lifetime average of .329. One of the first five players inducted to the Baseball Hall of Fame, he led the league in stolen bases on six occasions, finishing his career with a total of 722 steals. Wagner retired with more hits, runs, RBI, doubles, triples, games and steals than any other National League player. After his career as a player, Honus became a manager for his longtime team, the Pittsburgh Pirates. The Honus Wagner baseball card, one of the most valuable in existence today, was recalled in 1909. At the time, the cards were distributed along with tobacco; Wagner, a nonsmoker, objected to being included in the promotion because he did not want to set a bad example for children. from Honus Wagner Biography

I think the correct spelling for the town is "LLwyn y pia" sometimes spelt without spaces as "LLwynypia", not two capital "L"s since "LL" is a seperate letter in the Welsh alphabet. (there are other seperate letters represented by combinations of english letters e.g. CH, DD, FF, LL, RH)

LLwyn y pia is part of the county of "Rhondda Cynon Taf" as it is called today. Back when this photo was taken it was part of a very large County called "Glamorgan" which was split into 3 counties in the 1970s (South, Mid and West Glamorgan), and in the 1990s into many counties based more on the cities in them e.g. City and County of Swansea (formerly West Glamorgan).

You can get a good feeling of what life was like at the time shown in the photo by visiting several "living" museums in South Wales e.g. 

- St. Ffagans Heritage and Folk Museum - Outside Cardiff on the road A48 I think. They have a whole row of miner's cottages showing each house decorated for a different period e.g. early 1800s, mid 1800s, late 1800s, 1900 turn of century, 1940s, 1950s, 1980s, or similar - its like being in HG Well's time machine as you walk up the row of houses.

- Big Pit - Near Caerleon, town called Blaenavon - this is a MUST see - its a REAL coal mine, you go down several hundred feet in a cage elevator, then you walk around one of two routes underground with a guide - one tour takes you around the old types of mining - what it was like to be a kid in the mines, old equipment and workings, Pit pony stables (yes they used horses underground). The other route takes you around the modern mining area. The mine is inspected by government to commercial standards - ITS TOTALLY safe, the only reason civilians are allowed in the mine is you can also walk out of the mine by walking about 1km out of the side of the mountain (its also a drift mine as well as a deep navigation mine).

BOTH Museums are free (2008 time of writing). 

You can also read the books "Rape of the fair country" and "how green was my valley" by "Alexander Cordell" to understand what life was like in these communities in the industrial revolution (about 150 years before this).

To see a small town like this in film set at exactly the same time watch the film "The Englishman who went up a hill but came down a mountain" starring Colm Meaney and Hugh Grant - funny, lovely movie about a tight knit valley's community.

Incidentally my father was born in LLwyn y pia.
Yep its Llwynypia not Llwynpia - that would make it grove/bush magpie not grove.bus of the magpie. Grew up there and my sister was born in the hospital you can see on the hill at the back.

I second the Alexander Cordell books as recommended (essential!) reading around this subject matter. Llwynypia has never really recovered from the closure of the collieries, and even today, it is one of the areas listed in the new.wales.gov.uk/topics/statistics/publications/wimd08sum... available online, as well as this wonderful coal swathed portrait of 'John Davies aged 12, one of the many children used in the physically demanding and dangerous work-environment of the mine shafts. Average life expectancy was significantly reduced as the risk of colliery accidents were high. interestingly, after very little searching I've been able to find this reference to the death of George Henry Gaylard, who was born in Llwynypia in 1878, but died in an accident at Llwynypia colliery, aged 21 years. :( While he was born in the area, both his parents are recorded as having originated from Somerset. Whilst it isn't stated clearly, it appears that they probably moved over the border to Llwynypia for the employment opportunities offered by the presence of the colliery, where they subsequently stayed to raise their family. This 'sits' with my own family history, as my great-great-grandparents on my fathers side of the family, were from the area of Calne in Wiltshire, but moved to the Ebbw Vale/Brynmawr area of Wales (the county of Blaenau Gwent). My great-great grandfather and my great uncle were miners. My father recalls meeting my great-uncle after the shift was over, at the pit head, on many, many occasions; and coal blackened as he was, carrying dad home on his shoulders, where both would be chastised by my great-grandmother, for getting so dirty. Subsequently, a big metal bath tub would be taken off the hook and placed in front of a roaring fire, where it would then be filled with scalding water. The youngest member of the family (at that time, my father) would be plunged into the water first, scrubbed, hauled out, followed by the next oldest and so... Re-using the bathwater until every member of the family was clean.

Ok - I've found out some more. The owner of the Glamorgan coalmines, (who is described variously as a mining engineer and entrepreneur) was one Archibald Hood (1823-1902). According to this site here, and this site here, he grew up in Kilmarnock (East Ayrshire) in Scotland. This might explain why the 'Scotland' tag was attributed to some of the welsh coal mining images from this collection. The Llwynypia Colliery became strongly associated with Archibald Hood, and was known locally as 'The 'Scotch' Colliery. Archibald Hood was apparently brought up by his father (a widower), who was by trade, a colliery foreman. Hood himself started off with very little education and at the age of 12 was working in the mines himself. However, when his father became the manager of a colliery near Glasgow, Hood went on to study and qualify as a mining engineer. He then leased and operated pits/collieries all over the midlothian coalfields and developed a reputation as a moderniser, recognising that improving the conditions of the workers (both practically in the mines, and socially) would result in a more productive workforce. He went on to co-found the Lothian Coal Company in 1890, alongside Schomberg Kerr, 9th Marquess of Lothian (1833 - 1900) Hood began working in the welsh coalfields/collieries in 1862, when he established the Glamorgan Coal Company; modernising and extending the pits in the area. At its peak there were 140 coke ovens, and a large brickworks which Hood also founded. In 1908, the colliery became part of the Cambrian Combine, and the waste gases from the coking process, were also used to provide electricity for the colliery and to power the streetlights in the local communities. Hood actually moved to Wales in 1867, was very active in the civic life of the community in Cardiff and throughout Glamorgan, and was well liked. Although he maintained his management of the Scottish collieries, he lived in Cardiff where he eventually died and is buried. There is actually a statue/memorial to hood in Llwynypia, you can see a picture of that here. (Although it is somewhat dwarfed by the large number of people crowded nearby!) There is a really detailed history of Llwnypia here, which is fascinating. It also confirms that the name 'Llwynypia' translates from Welsh to English as '‚ÄòThe grove of the bush of the magpie' and 'derives its name from a farm that stood on the land pre-industrialisation'. The 1910 Cambrian Combine Miners Strike & Tonypandy Riot is covered here. (The strike itself became popularly known as The Tonypandy Riot.) It has become renown for being one of the few occasions in British history when troops were deployed against British workers. The strike began on August 01st 1910, and was a bitter dispute, with widespread consequences for miners across the region. The link outlines this in some detail.
Thanks!  We'll look into the spelling of "Llwynypia", and thanks for the detailed information on collieries.

From the time of the 1912 (negative is dated) minimum wage strike which lasted 12 weeks

That's not a date, it's a reference number.

Which doesn't mean it's not the 1912 strike, just that we don't have a date to confirm it.

The two British coal strikes which the press photographically documented between 1910 and 1915 were the 1911 and 1912 strikes with the 1912 minimum wage strike featuring most strongly, it's tantalising to think that -12 means 1912!

If you look at a range of the photos from this collection on glass slides they all have a reference number, four digits, hyphen, one or two digits.  When they have a date, it's been scratched onto the back and shows up as thin mirror writing.

So it still could be either 1911 or 1912.

Oh Titanic ! 
Oh Titanic we morn for thee, 
we remember the old days you us to see ,
 sailing the deep blue see.

the crown of England

Men , Mother, Children forgetting to bring a life boat,
rushed to their rooms searching for love ones.
Children crying holding their tummies,
well mothers cry for their love ones that were dying.

GEN. KEARNY'S BODY LIES IN CITY HALL; Military Pomp Marks Removal of Noted Fighter's Remains from Trinity Church. April 12, 1912, Friday Page 8, 1254 words With military honors so elaborate as to halt downtown traffic and office work for some time during the busy forenoon yesterday, the coffin containing the remains of Major Gen. Philip Kearny was removed from Trinity Church, and, after being carried on a flag-draped caisson though lower Broadway was placed in the rotunda of City Hall to remain there in state overnight. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9402E7DF153CE633A... He was killed in the Civil War. So what is happening here? (from bio of Kearny on line): "His remains, forwarded under a flag of truce by Robert E. Lee, were first buried in Trinity Churchyard in New York City, but on April 12, 1912 were moved to Arlington National Cemetery. His grave is marked by one of only two equestrian statues in the cemetery and was a gift of the people of New Jersey in 1914." JOSHUA CRANE BEATS PENNELL AT TENNIS; American Qualifies to Play Jay Gould for American Title at Racquet Club. April 12, 1912, Friday Page 11, 968 words Jay Gould, the American champion court tennis player, refereed the match in the final round of the series arranged to provide an opponent for him in the challenge match for the American title scheduled for to-morrow, and witnessed the triumph of an American. Joshua Crane of Boston, over Vane Pennell of England, by a score of three sets to two, after a series of games which bristled with keen play. SHOTS FIRED AT KING OF ITALY; Major Langa Hit by Anarchist's Bullet as He Screens Victor Emmanuel. March 15, 1912, Friday ROME, March 14. -- Throughout Italy there is rejoicing to-night over the escape of the King and Queen, at whom a young Anarchist named Antonio Dalba fired several shots this morning as their Majesties were proceeding to the Pantheon to take part in the annual memorial service in memory of the late King Humbert, who was born on March 14, 1844, and who was killed by the Anarchist Bresci at Monza on July 29, 1900. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990CE1DB143CE633A... Botany Worsted Mills was in Passaic NJ. The workers went on strike March 27 1912. they wanted recognition of their union and a minimum wage of $3 per day.

More on the strike: "The good judgment of the [police] chief and his men was shown in the handling of strikers during the general strike in the mills in [M]arch, 1912. The strikers became so riotous that the mill owners called on the sheriff for assistance and he sent forty deputies who were powerless and it devolved upon the police to quiet the men and induce them to return to work, after five weeks of strenuous work, during which not a man, woman or child was even seriously wounded and none was killed." [From "A History of Passaic and Its Environs (Volume II, Historical-Biographical)" by William W. Scott (1922) archive.org/stream/historyofpassaic02scot/historyofpassai... ]
More info about this strike at www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163064455

Another interesting player from the "dead ball era." He played almost all of his major league career in one season, for the 1912 Philadelphia Athletics. He led the Pacific Coast League in runs in 1913 (128), 1914 (127), 1915 (147), and 1919 (127). Also led the PCL in 3B in 1913 (23) and 1915 (14), and hit 20 3B in 1914 to finish one behind the leaders. Maggert (senior) was considered "temperamental" and "difficult toward managers". It was his acceptance of $300 from Babe Borton that led to the investigation into the allegation of games being thrown in the PCL. Received lifetime ban in 1920. source: www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Harl_Maggert_(maggeha01) Of interest, his son, also named Harl Maggert, also played all his major league career in one season, for the 1938 Boston Bees, managed by Casey Stengel.

Post Civil War Late 1800's Boxing was the next best thing from gun slinging. With the Queensbury Rules instated, boxing became more popular were it was not.. A very well documented beginning www.flickr.com/photos/25210547@N02/2380728650/ A grand begining Here is two of the boxing greats www.youtube.com/watch?v=BOFdL5VkcQM . www.youtube.com/watch?v=37OcLWu1T_E . www.youtube.com/watch?v=mTk4SdcpAwc&feature=related . www.youtube.com/watch?v=8iShuZvyDHA&feature=related . en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquess_of_Queensberry_rules The Queensbury Rules . 1 To be a fair stand-up boxing match in a twenty-four foot ring or as near that size as practicable. 2. No wrestling or hugging allowed. 3. The rounds to be of three minutes duration and one minute time between rounds. 4. If either man fall through weakness or otherwise, he must get up unassisted, ten seconds be allowed to do so, the other man meanwhile to return to his corner; and when the fallen man is on his legs the round is to be resumed and continued until the three minutes have expired. If one man fails to come to the scratch in the ten seconds allowed, it shall be in the power of the referee to give his award in favor of the other man. 5. A man hanging on the ropes in a helpless state, with his toes off the ground, shall be considered down. 6. No seconds or any other person to be allowed in the ring during the rounds. 7. Should the contest be stopped by any unavoidable interference, the referee (is) to name the time and place as soon as possible for finishing the contest, to that the match can be won and lost, unless the backers of the men agree to draw the stakes. 8. The gloves to be fair-sized boxing gloves of the best quality and new. 9. Should a glove burst, or come off, it must be replaced to the referee's satisfaction. 10. A man on one knee is considered down, and if struck is entitled to the stakes. 11. No shoes or boots with springs allowed. 12. The contest in all other respects to be governed by the revised rules of the London Prize Ring. HURRICANE www.youtube.com/watch?v=few4kiKjNzw read on and on

This was the City Hall Post Office, originally between Broadway and Park Row in New York City. Its architect was A.B. Mullett. Built in 1878, it was maligned in its time as "Mullett's Monstrosity," and demolished in 1939. Roads and part of City Hall's park stand there today. The Municipal Building (which is still around) is shown under construction in the background.
Mullett also designed the Old (Eisenhower) Executive Office Building in D.C., which looks very similar: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Executive_Office_Building

1912 Lawrence textile strike en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1912_Lawrence_textile_strike The Lawrence Textile Strike, also known as the Bread and Roses Strike, was a strike of immigrant workers in Lawrence, Massachusetts, in 1912 led by the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW). Prompted by a two-hour pay cut corresponding to a new law shortening the workweek for women, the strike spread rapidly through the town, growing to more than twenty thousand workers and involving nearly every mill in Lawrence. On January 1, 1912, the Massachusetts government enforced a law that cut mill workers' hours in a single work week from 56 hours, to 54 hours. Ten days later, they found out that pay had been reduced along with the cut in hours. (Source: Wikipedia)

Chris Hernandez: I wasn't sure whether you were saying that your print is a reproduction from the Library of Congress collections or that you have a print from somewhere else. If it was obtained from the Library of Congress, it would be surprising if it were cropped unless you (or the person who originally requested it) asked to have it cropped. That makes me wonder if your print might have been printed from a variant negative. I notice, for instance, that we seem to have a very close variant, viewable in our online catalog at: http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.29882. It doesn't exactly look cropped to me, but it does seem to show what appears to be a glimmer of sunlight, rather than a water stain, in the region you mention. I'm assuming when you ask about restoring, you are suggesting that we alter our digital file. Our practice when we digitize is to try to represent the artifact as faithfully as possible for the sake of both research and preservation. Original negatives often exhibit signs of deterioration, and we do not attempt to correct those flaws in the scanning process. With images such as this, which have "no known copyright restrictions," people may choose to alter or adjust the file when they use it. Please let me know if I haven't understood your question. It sent me on an interesting exploration of Mexican Revolution images in the Bain Collection!

Between 1910 and 1915 took place only two manned free balloon flights in Mexico City, both in early 1914: On the Sunday, January 25, the mexican aviation pioneer Alberto Braniff Ricard (1885-1966) and the french technician Jules Dubois flew on a 2,200 m3 Gordon Bennett hydrogen-filled balloon just brought from France by Braniff himself. They took off from a Braniff's plot beside the former Colonia Railway Station (Estaci√≥n Colonia) near the Paseo de la Reforma avenue (the balloon in the photograph seems to be above this place). As a Braniff¬¥s guest were aboard the legendary mexican ballooning pioneer Joaqu√≠n de la Cantolla y Rico (1829-1914), at that time already an elder man, who would die three days later. The second flight took off on the Saturday, January 31, in the same place and on the same Gordon Bennett balloon manned by Braniff and Dubois. "Joe Edwards" was the alias for the welterweight German boxer Paul Maschke from Berlin, who was a contender in the 'mixed rules' (boxing/wrestling) events that were taking place in parts of Europe. "Joe Edwards" was the light-weight champion in London in 1900, and in addition to an active fighting schedule, "Joe Edwards" authored books on Boxing ("Boxen. Ein Fechten mit Naturwaffen" translated: "Boxing. Fencing with nature weapons‚Äù), taught at the Berlin Boxing Club and ran the "Berlin School of Boxing", ("American-Athletic-Club") in Berlin. [1] [2] On February 1, 1907, Paul Maschke ('Joe Edwards') (Boxing) defeated the Frenchman, Edmond Vary (Jiu Jitsu) in Berlin. There was a rematch on August 11, 1907, between Maschke and Vary (Jiu Jitsu), also in Berlin. One source states that Vary lost again, another, a newspaper article from August 18, 1907, calls it a draw. [3] [4] [5] Joe's wife, Rose "Edwards" was also a boxer. Two photographs of her are featured on Flickr.   There are other (LOC) photographs of "Joe Edwards" here:             "Joe Edwards"           by LOC             "Joe Edwards"           by LOC

The London Stereoscopic Company was founded in 1854 by George S. Nottage. As well as producing photographs, the company acted as a retailer for photographic equipment. The firm was successful in all branches of photography. From 1860 to 1862 the company was based at 54 Cheapside, London. From 1860 to 1861 it also had premise at 313 Oxford Street. In 1863 the company occupied 54 Cheapside and 110 Regent Street. From 1864 onwards it occupied a variety of locations on Cheapside, Regent Street and Bow Churchyard. The company was known by several slightly different names. In 1863 it is referred to as the London Stereoscopic and Photographic Co. and C. de V. Institute. From 1864 it was known as the London Stereoscopic and Photographic Co. Ltd.

Artist associated with 407 portraits
The London Stereoscopic Company was founded in 1854 by George S. Nottage, and was still in business in 1908. It was successful in all branches of photography, but specialised in the mass production of stereoscopic photographs. The firm's output was vast; there were over 100,000 stereo photographs listed in its 1858 catalogue. The company was known by several slightly different names. In 1863 it is referred to as the London Stereoscopic and Photographic Co. and C. de V. Institute. From 1864 it was known as the London Stereoscopic and Photographic Co. Ltd. The firm occupied a variety of premises on Oxford Street, Regent Street, Cheapside and Bow Churchyard. Its archive is now held by Getty Images.

During the suggested date range, the Fram was sailed by Amundsen to the Antarctic. On 10 August 1910 she left Norway. On 14 December 1911, Amundsen, Hanssen, Bjaaland, Hassel and Wisting reached the South Pole. She stopped briefly at Hobart before heading round Cape Horn to Buenos Aires, waited for some weeks at Colon to try and be the first ship through the Panama Canal to no avail (one newspaper report suggested her mainmast was too tall), set out for the Bering Strait via Cape Horn but abandoned the attempt (and did not apparently reach San Francisco as planned) and returned to Buenos Aires. In 1914, she was ordered back to Norway and then found to have dry rot. I find no clues as to where this picture might have been taken -- although it clearly was not in the Antarctic!!. Plenty of pictures, including in the article below, confirm that the photo is indeed of the famous Fram. See pubs.aina.ucalgary.ca/arctic/Arctic42-4-384.pdf and www.fram.museum.no/en/ Puzzlingly, it is in pictures from an earlier (1898-1902) expedition to the Arctic that she has a coat of light-colored paint as here. In the pictures identified from the Amundsen trip, she looks dark.
Thanks for the information and for citing your source!  We‚Äôll update the source description and reload the record.

The Fram is more famous to me for her association with the scientist-explorer-humanitarian Fridtjof Nansen than with Amundsen.  In 1893 Nansen attempted to reach the North Pole by deliberately allowing the Fram to freeze into the ice pack and then be passively carried across the pole by currents (which he had deduced, based on patterns of deposition of driftwood and articles from the shipwreck Jeannette) would cross the North Pole).  When, after a year in the ice, it became clear that the Fram would miss the Pole in her Arctic traverse, Nansen and one of his officers left the ship and tried to reach the pole on foot.  Their journey is chronicled in Nansen's excellent book "Farthest North".
That appears to me as a photo of a painting and not of the ship itself.
www.flickr.com/photos/national_library_of_norway/tags/fram/ finds many pictures of the Fram, from both the Nansen and Amundsen explorations

Albert Kahn has a very similar autochrone (colour photograph) of the damage done to a shop in Piccadilly Circus by the Suffragettes in 1911.
Heroes to the last !

The damage was aimed at shops who supplied the king (by appointment to HRH).

It seems almost certain that this photo and www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163047923 both show the aftermath of the same event, which had occurred on March 1, 1912. It may also be that the photo in this collection titled "London - arrest of a suffragette" is also showing a consequence of the same event, but there isn't enough context to say. The event was the subject of a news story on page 8 of The Times for the following day. Its title was "Suffragist Outrages | Wholesale Window Smashing in London | Attack on the Prime Minister's House". Included in the story were express references to the smashing of shop windows in Bond Street and in Regent Street. This photo is showing shops in Bond Street, while the other photo I mentioned in the first paragraph is showing a shop in Regent Street, as was pointed out by the third commenter on that photo.
In the US the women were suffragettes, but in the UK they were called suffragists

revans1953:

Thanks for the comment.  Interestingly, the term suffragist has also become the accepted subject term in our cataloging here at the Library, rather than suffragette. In the case of this photograph, we have transcribed an original caption, and since that caption was written by an American agency for the U.S. audience, it reflects the term in common American parlance at the time.

revans1953 says:
In the US the women were suffragettes, but in the UK they were called suffragists 
 
Actually the militants (the ladies who broke the law and fought back) were called suffragettes on both sides of the pond.  The suffragists were a different group altogether who stayed on the right side of the law and thought that debating the issue would win the day.

The window smashing would have indeed been carried out by suffragettes, probably members of the WSPU (Women's Social and Political Union) who's slogan was 'Deeds Not Words'

Mrs. T.

I stand corrected. Thanks very much.

John Emery Harriman of Brookline, Massachusetts held a U.S. Patent for a "Flying Machine," but the patent drawings do not much resemble the aircraft in this picture. Patent number: 972448 Filing date: Feb 8, 1904 Issue date: Oct 11, 1910 However, the issue date on the patent is the same specified on this illustration, so it is clear that Harriman thought this aircraft was a variation on his invention. Harriman also held a number of other patents, for example a flatiron, a pipe-coupling device, and a rotary engine.

"Joe Edwards" was the alias for the welterweight German boxer Paul Maschke, who was a contender in the 'mixed rules' (boxing/wrestling) events that were taking place in parts of Europe. On February 1, 1907, Paul Maschke ('Joe Edwards') (Boxing) defeated the Frenchman, Edmond Vary (Jiu Jitsu) in Berlin. There was a rematch on August 11, 1907, between Maschke and Vary (Jiu Jitsu), also in Berlin. One source states that Vary lost again, another, a newspaper article from August 18, 1907, calls it a draw. [1] [2] [3] On May 17, 1908, in Copenhagen. Paul Maschke ('Joe Edwards') lost in a match with welterweight Johannes J√∏rgensen, (1867-1913), who used the alias "Jim Smith", [4] Joe's wife, Rose "Edwards" was also a boxer. Two photographs of her are featured on Flickr. Rose Pitonof was from Dorchester MA, first female swimmer to swim from Manhattan to Coney Island, in August 1911, when she was 17 years old. The year before, she had completed the Boston Light swim. See South Boston: My Home Town: The History of an Ethnic Neighborhood by Thomas H. O'Connor (University Press of New England 1994). She was featured on a chewing tobacco card c.1913: www.bikiniscience.com/chronology/1910-1915_SS/PS1350_S/PS...

Via the Coney Island History Project's Facebook page On this day in history...Sept 18,1910... Rose Pitonof swam from the New York Yacht Club at the foot of East Twenty-third Street to Coney Island Lightship, a distance of 16-1/4 miles in a straight line, without any noticeable fatigue on her part. The 16 year old girl from Boston accomplished what male swimmers had tried... time and again without success. Rounding Norton's Point, she had a royal battle with the head tide. She made the distance in 5 hours and 8 minutes. Photo: Rose Pitonof, Champion Long-Distance Swimmer, Library of Congress, Bain collection www.facebook.com/pages/Coney-Island-History-Project/14934...

Here's a little more information on this quartet.. They left Hawaii on February 12, 1012, smothered in leis, heading for the olympic trials."Accompanying Duke was another Olympic hopeful, the distance swimmer, Vincent "Zen" Genoves, as well as the expedition manager, Lew Henderson, and last minute addition, E.K. "Dude" Miller. " 100 Years Ago Today - Duke Leaves Hawaii It was on this day, February 7th, in 1912 that Duke Kahanamoku left Hawaii for the first time. He was on his way to the Olympic Trials on the mainland. Duke had recently smashed swimming records at the Amateur Athletic Union's first swim meet in the Territory of Hawaii and much hope was being placed on sending Duke to the mainland to represent Hawaii. ‚ÄúIt would be a good thing for Hawaii from an advertising standpoint if Kahanamoku were sent to San Francisco to take part in the trials. Win or lose, he can be relied on to make a credible showing‚Äù ‚Äì H.M. Ayres, sportswriter for The Hawaiian Star, January 4th 1912. Duke and his travelling partners "were literally smothered with leis and were the recipients of countless good wishes from friends and well-wishers." (Hawaiian Star - February 8th, 1912). Accompanying Duke was another Olympic hopeful, the distance swimmer, Vincent "Zen" Genoves, as well as the expedition manager, Lew Henderson, and last minute addition, E.K. "Dude" Miller. "It was decided at the last moment to send Miller along. He knows the boys intimately and can talk Hawaiian, a fact which should be of great help to the expedition as far as Kahanamoku is concerned." It was Duke's first time leaving the islands. Presumably this shot was when they were on the East Coast for Olympic swimming trials there. americanpaddleboard.blogspot.com/2012/02/100-years-ago-to...

USS Lydonia (SP-700) was a 497 gross ton yacht acquired by the U.S. Navy during World War I. She was outfitted as a patrol craft and spent most of the war based out of Gibraltar, escorting and protecting Allied ships in the Mediterranean and along the Atlantic Ocean coast of Europe. Post-war she was transferred to the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey as USCGS Lydonia (CS-302). It is named after William A. Lydon. William A. Lydon and Fred C. Drews founded the Lydon & Drews dredging company in Chicago. I started an article on him here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_A._Lydon Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Lydonia_(SP-700)

This is a team photo of the BFC Viktoria 1889 (Berliner Fu√üball-Club Viktoria 1889), a Berlin soccer team that won the German national soccer championship in 1894, 1908 and 1911. This photo appears to have been taken in 1911 or 1912, around the time of the club's last national championship (the outfits are consistent with those worn in another championship photo from 1911, while the 1908 team was wearing knee-length shorts). 

The handwritten ID on the photograph uses the English spelling "Victoria". However, the more commonly used German spelling is "Viktoria".

Heinie Groh, a great player that used a "bottle bat".  The bottle bat made it easier to make contact with the ball, but it did not allow one to hit the ball as far.  The last major leaguer that I recall using a bottle bat was Nellie Fox.  In fact, I have a Louisville Slugger Nelson Fox bottle bat.  Fox got a lot of spray singles using the bottle bat.  He very seldom hit a homer.  Groh played during the "dead ball" era and it was more important to make contact and "hit 'em where they ain't" as Wee Willie Keeler once said.

Packy McFarland was born in 1888. He achieved great recognition as a prize fighter. Over his career he earned over $200,000 in prize money. In 1991 the Guinness Book of Records noted he had 97 fights (5 draws) without defeat from 1905-1915. He went on to serve on the Illinois Boxing Commission. He would die at his home in 1936 of step throat. At his funeral, over 3,000 people attended with then Governor of Illinois Henry Horner leading the funeral procession.

Patrick "Packey" McFarland (November 1, 1888, in Chicago, IL ‚Äî September 22, 1936) a popular American boxer who was a title contender in the lightweight and welterweight divisions. The Ring Record Book and Boxing Encyclopedia suggests he was the greatest fighter never to win a world title. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packey_McFarland
Another Bain Collection photo from the same session:

Packy was managed by Harry Gilmore Jr., whom Bain photographed with another of his fighters, Spike Kelly. Harry's father, Prof. Harry Gilmore, is also in a Bain photo.

Packy's fame was such that a prominent physician in my hometown of Ames, Iowa, Dr. Julian McFarland, was nicknamed Packy.

That is a picture of Luna Island. Luna Island has a man-made bridge over to it from Goat Island. 
The Ice Bridge forms (as in ettenw's photo) when the ice would build up in the lower river below the Rainbow Bridge. You could walk out onto the ice and during prohibition shanties would be set up on the ice to sell booze. 
They stopped allowing people to walk out onto the ice in 1912 after a early thaw caused the ice to break up. Three people were killed.
getglassy:  Thank you for the interesting history of the ice bridge and Luna Island.  We will include the information in our description of the photograph when the database is updated.
That is the Honeymoon bridge in the photo. The Honeymoon bridge collapsed in 1938 and was replaced with the Rainbow Bridge.

@strangerer: the LOC photos (November 27, 1911) of visiting British Suffragette Emmeline Pankhurst on Wall Street, haranguing a crowd of gormless young males, do not show a parade. According to a story in the New York Times (November 28, 1911), this was a previously-announced speaking event, with only one vehicle involved. Since the city provided no police protection, and the ladies were shouted down and unable to make themselves heard, they soon gave up the attempt and instead drove to police headquarters to file a complaint.

The building in this photograph is the Cowtown Coliseum  (built in the winter of 1907-08 in 88 working days) on East Exchange Avenue in the Fort Worth Stockyards.   It is still in use today, but not for the annual Livestock show.   The Fort Worth Livestock Show moved to Will Rogers Coliseum in 1940 because it had outgrown this venue.  The stock show has been there ever since.  

I am a former Stockyards tour guide who gave tours through this building.   It's a beauty.

Hello Evangar21: Noticed your interest in more Philippines photos. You'll find other images relating to the Philippine Islands between the period 1890 and 1945 in the Prints & Photographs Division online catalog ("PPOC") (www.loc.gov/rr/print/catalog.html). Try searching the catalog using the following two keywords [without quotes]: "Philippines" "photographic prints". You should get over 400 results from different sources within your time frame.  (Of course, adding additional  keywords will narrow your search results to specific topics).  And, a broader search using only the keyword Philippines will get you even more pictures in a variety of formats in addition to photographs.

I do not think this is Boston. As far as I know, there have only been a couple old elevated streetcar lines, and I do not recall any of them looking like this. The second paragraph on the link below indicates that this picture may well have been taken in Sioux City: genforum.genealogy.com/sellon/messages/101.html

As far as I can see, the streetcars are running UNDER the bridge, which is for an elevated electric train, like those in New York, Chicago and Boston.  Sioux City elevated railway was closed in 1899 and as far as I know, it hadn¬¥t streetcars tracks under it.

It could certainly be Boston. The sign in the upper right references the  Boston Candy Store. Also, there were elevated railways in Boston beyond just the portion of the Green and Red Lines that remain above ground and elevated. What's now the Orange Line was at one point elevated, too. The Essex Street station was a copper-clad building, now preserved at the Trolley Museum in Kennebunkport, Maine. It would be interesting to see if the steel girders matched the preserved station. 

That said, if this is Boston, it's most likely near North Station.

Krupp is a German armsmaker, known to have sent anti-ship guns to the Dardanelles to Germany's ally Turkey.  These guns are designed to sink ships, and they did great damage during the naval incursion attempt of the allied navy on March 18, 1915.  As the label says AFTER bombardment, and that it's written in English and that they could get so close to take this photo strongly suggests the photo was taken during the land campaign during which several points in the Dardanelles peninsula were captured by the allies temporarily.

Hi Princewolf: Thanks for investigating the background to this photo. However, I think it depicts the Italo-Turkish War of 1911 rather than the later Gallipoli Campaign of World War I. According to The Dictionary of Battles and Sieges (Tony Jaques, Greenwood Publishing Group, 2007, p. 941) in 1911 fighting between the Italian and Turko-Arab forces took place in Sidi Mesri, Libya with the Italians eventually taking over the location. See information here at Google Books: books.google.com/books?id=sbMFCZyAcnQC&pg=PA941&l...

We don't do "Thanksgiving Masking" any more, but it is an interesting custom, involving children dressed as beggars begging for coins. A very interesting account of the history of Thanksgiving notes: "Progressive era reformers regarded child begging on Thanksgiving as immoral and thought children who engaged in it should be arrested. Why were parents not able to control their offspring? the New York Times in 1903 wanted to know.(30) The newspaper castigated parents who allowed children to demand treats or money as indecent.(31) The police tried to enforce a ban against begging. In response to complaints from the public, the clergy, school superintendents, and classroom teachers issued warnings. The New York Times in November of 1930 worried that demanding coins could teach children to become professional beggars and blackmailers and that children were annoying the public.(32) Begging, decided the paper, was a "malicious influence on the morals of children of the city."(33) Boys' clubs and other child welfare agencies organized parades and costume contests as alternative activities. As a result of these efforts, child begging on Thanksgiving finally disappeared by the 1940s.(34) " www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-55083998.html?Q="mumming The tradition went back as far as 1780, involving crossdressing men who called themselves the Fantastics and paraded on the holiday.

While visiting my grandmother today and talking about the Super Bowl, she recalled the Army/Navy game of 1911.  She was 5 years old and remembered that the Navy won.  She told us of her father and her grandfather working in a factory with something called a ticker.  There were no telephones and only one means of communication at the factory.  This was available in the event there was an emergency to contact a doctor.  Her father and grandfather went into the office to hear the news of the game.  She said it was the game of the century!  It is amazing how much she remember of those days.  Even at 102 her mind is almost perfect and she is so much fun to talk to.  She can remember every President and their name in order since the age of 5.  It appears that from 5 years on she has pretty much total memory recall.

Other Bain/LOC photos of visiting British Suffragette leader Emmeline Pankhurst, addressing (or attempting to address) a rowdy, noisy crowd of young males beside the Subtreasury Building on Wall Street, New York City, on November 27, 1911:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163792086/]
With Mrs. Pankhurst in the open car are Hariot Stanton Blatch, U. S. Suffragist leader, and the venerable Dr. Anna Howard Shaw.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2423482538/in/photostream/]

Mrs. Pankhurst made a return visit to America in October, 1913. On that occasion, foolish U. S. immigration officials decided to bar entry to her, holding her at Ellis Island for deportation. This created a cause celebre, and required the personal intervention of U. S. President Woodrow Wilson to admit her for an already-scheduled lecture tour. The publicity helped suffragist fundraising enormously.

Date on glass negative is 10/28/11. During October 1911, over 100 naval ships assembled in New York for a Naval Review by the President of the United States (Theodore Roosevelt). See query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9905E6DC1539E333A... and the PDF it points to. It lists these submarines among the vessels to be present. Salem is the warship in the background. Many of the photos of naval vessels in this batch of Bain photos were probably taken around New York during October or early November 1911. However, there was also a Naval Review in New York the following year.

Thanks for pinning down the date and the event! The "Salem" may be a sub called the "Salmon" and the ship in the background may be the Nebraska, according to comment with www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2162989549/

The three on the left are D-class subs. There were only three in this class, so these have to be Narwhal, Grayling, and Salmon. The three on the right are C-class, which includes Tarpon, Octopus, and Bonita, as well as Stingray and Snapper which apparently couldn't make it that day. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_C_class_submarine en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_D_class_submarine I spoke too soon, looks like Stingray and Snapper were tied up on the other side. I suspect there's a limit to how many subs can be lined up at once. Note the negatives are both labeled 2335, so probably taken at the same event. www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163790206/
given the lack of line up number between the BB funnels, this is most likely the 1911 event.

Tarpon, Octopus, and Bonita were C class subs, Grayling was D class. All were renamed on 17 November 1911 so this photo may have been taken prior to that date. I can't find a "Salem" but I wonder if that's really the Salmon, another D class. Subs were all named for fish at the time so "Salem" seems unlikely. Salmon was commissioned in Sept 1910 so that helps to further date the photo.

The photo was probably taken at Newport, Rhode Island, as that's where all these subs operated out of.

Source: Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships, via wikipedia.

The "Dept. of Docks & Ferries" label on the dock definitely places it in NYC. The gas tank in the background would have been part of a manufacturd gas plant facility. The caption refers to warships. but the date is six years before America's entry into WWI. The only places warships would have been "watched" in 1911 would most likely have been the East River around the Navy yard, or on the Hudson, near Hoboken. There aren't really any streets terminating at the river around the Navy yard that would have ended in "...th". However, 14th Street on the west side of Manhattan was a very busy embarkation point for ferries to New Jersey. Also, according to Con Ed records, there was a major gas plant between 16th and 20th Streets along the Hudson. And that bridge behind the buildings looks to be about where the old  High Line elevated railway once stood. So maybe this is the 14th Street Ferry?

Helen Preece would have been, at 15, the only female competitor in the 1912 Olympics, however was turned down by the Swedish Olympic Committee on the grounds that she was female. www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1912/MOP/mens-in...
oh! that is so awful.

Reading the interesting article cited above, it appears to me that it was more a problem with the British Olympic Association than the Swedish! The British Secretary is applying the letter of the law to block her entry. The Swedish response seems to admit that the rules are somewhat out of step. Even Coubertin (founder of the modern Olympics) refers to her derogatively, but begrudgingly admits there is a problem with the rules - while passing the buck! Their problem appears to be that a lady is directly competing with men (women were competing separately in other events), but equestrianism is now one of the relatively few events where there is no gender issue. I expect Miss Preece was probably advised that it would be deemed 'unladylike' to pursue the matter.... :-/

Reverend Clarence Virgil Thompson Richeson (February 15, 1876 - May 21, 1912) was executed for the sensationalized murder of Avis Willard Linnell. Avis Linnell ‚Äúcommitted suicide‚Äù October 14, 1911 at the YWCA in Boston. The story got the attention of Edwin Grozier, owner of the Boston Post, who assigned every available reporter to the story. Hobart was the great-great-grandaughter of Martha Ballard, a New England midwife whose late-18th-century diary was the source material for the fascinating scholarly book "A Midwife's Tale" (Random House, 1991), by Laurel Thatcher Ulrich. 

Ulrich writes that in 1930, Hobart gave the diary to the Maine State Library in Augusta. In a letter written at the time, she summarized her own life in a few brisk sentences, referring to herself in the third person:

"The doctor, who likes to believe that the mantle of her gifted ancestor fell on her shoulders, was born in Boston, 1851 -- She graduated from the Woman's Medical College of the New York Infirmary, in 1884, and carried on her medical work in Boston until 1913, when she retired to private life and took up her residence at Needham Heights, Mass. During the thirty years of her professional life, she was associated with the New England Hospital for Women and Children of Boston."

Ulrich also gives some details of Hobart's career:

Hobart began her professional life at the famous New York Infirmary for Women and Children, founded by Dr. Elizabeth Blackwell, the first woman in the United States to graduate from medical school. Blackwell had hoped that other women might follow in her footsteps, but when established medical colleges, including her own alma mater, Geneva College, closed their doors to female students, she was forced to open her own. Thanks to Blackwell's efforts and those of others like her, female physicians comprised about 5 percent of the profession in the late nineteenth century, a figure that changed little until the 1960s.

Mary Hobart spent the remainder of her professional life at another landmark institution: the New England Hospital, founded in 1862 by Dr. Marie Zakrzewska, was the second hospital in the United States run by women for women. Unabashedly separatist, it survived into the middle of the twentieth century, simultaneously committed to high professional standards and to female control.

The year Mary Hobart received the diary was an important one for the female physicians of Boston. On June 10, 1884, after more than thirty years of debate, the Massachusetts Medical Society voted (63 to 47) to admit women as members.

Suffragist and social economist M. Edith Campbell was elected to the Board of Education in Cincinnati in 1911, with the endorsement of President Taft himself. Her 1910 essay "Employment Bureaus for Women" can be found on Google Books, in a collection called The Economic Position of Women See Betty B. Ames, "Mary Edith Campbell: Cincinnati's First Woman Citizen," Bulletin of the Historical and Philosophical Society of Ohio 21(April 1963): 133-138.

Marie Curie (born Maria Sk≈Çodowska, also known as Marie Curie-Sk≈Çodowska; November 7, 1867 ‚Äì July 4, 1934) was a physicist and chemist of Polish upbringing and, subsequently, French citizenship. She was a pioneer in the field of radioactivity, the first twice-honored Nobel laureate (and still the only one in two different sciences) and the first female professor at the University of Paris.

She was born in Warsaw, Congress Poland, Russian Empire, and lived there until she was 24. In 1891 she followed her elder sister to study in Paris, where she obtained her higher degrees and conducted her scientific work. She founded the Curie Institutes in Paris and Warsaw. She was the wife of fellow-Nobel-laureate Pierre Curie and the mother of a third Nobel laureate, Ir√®ne Joliot-Curie.

The New York City garbage strike was put down by a massive hiring of strikebreakers, but outbursts of resistance continued until the end of November, as documented by stories in The New York Times. Cleanup efforts dragged on into December. "Strikers Plead to be Taken Back" New York Times story, November 21, 1911: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A02E3DC1231E2...
Seven of these 14 photos bear the date 11/13/11; the other seven are undated.

Dear CaroleGmomof3: I imagine you can learn more about the 1911 garbage strike in a book on New York City history. Here are a couple of titles which sounded interesting to me from our catalog. They may be available at a library near you: 1) Main Title: The Greater city, New York, 1898-1948 / edited by Allan Nevins and John A. Krout. Published/Created: Westport, Conn. : Greenwood Press, 1981, c1948. lccn.loc.gov/81004173 2) Main Title: Incredible New York : high life and low life from 1850 to 1950 / Lloyd Morris. Edition Information: 1st Syracuse University Press ed. Published/Created: New York : Syracuse University Press, 1996. lccn.loc.gov/95046297 Hope this helps.

I'm not 100% certain, but this may be 50th Street and First Avenue in New York City. The gabled building in the distance looks a lot like 931 First Avenue a.k.a. the United Nations School a.k.a. Public School 135 a.k.a. Public School 35, originally built in 1892. This building was recently been redeveloped into the the Beekman Regent, so some of its architectural features have been removed. And just as in the photo, there's an address with an 891 only a block away from it.

Wanamaker is properly spelled with only one "n." This is the roof of the Wanamaker store in New York City, where the balloon was tethered for several days while it was filled with hydrogen gas made on the spot by pouring sulphuric acid over iron filings. It was planned that the balloon would be launched and steered toward Philadelphia, but the pilot got lost in fog and landed in West Nyack instead. Here's the story from the New York Times, July 9, 1911: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9506E0D71431E233A... Byron Bancroft "Ban" Johnson (January 5, 1864 ‚Äì March 28, 1931), was an American executive in professional baseball who served as the founder and first president of the American League (AL).

Johnson developed the AL, a descendant of the minor league Western League, into a "clean" alternative to the National League, which had become notorious for its rough-and-tumble atmosphere.[1] To encourage a more orderly environment, Johnson provided unwavering support to the new league's umpires,[2] which later included Hall of Famer Billy Evans.[3]

With the help of league owners and managers such as Charles Comiskey, Charles Somers and Jimmy McAleer, Johnson lured top talent to the AL, which soon rivaled the more established National League.[4] Johnson ruled the AL with an iron fist until the 1920s, when a public dispute with Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis culminated in his forced resignation as league president.[2]

August "Garry" Herrmann (May 3, 1859 - April 25, 1931) was an American executive in Major League Baseball who served as president of the Cincinnati Reds of the National League from 1902 to 1927. As the president of baseball's National Commission from 1903 to 1920, he is often regarded as having filled the role of Baseball Commissioner before that position was officially established in 1920. With two other Commission members he established the annual nature of the World Series by 1905. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_Herrmann

John Tomlinson Brush (June 15, 1845 - November 26, 1912) was an American sports executive who was the owner of the New York Giants franchise in Major League Baseball from 1890 until his death. He also owned the Indianapolis Hoosiers in the late 1880s, and the Cincinnati Reds from 1891 to 1902. Under his leadership, the Giants were revived as a franchise after a decline during the 1890s. Brush was also a leader in the formation of the rules that govern the modern World Series. He was one of 11 executives who were honored by the Baseball Hall of Fame on a Roll of Honor in 1946.

Cornelius McGillicuddy (December 22, 1862 ‚Äì February 8, 1956), better known as Connie Mack, was an American professional baseball player, manager, and team owner. The longest-serving manager in Major League Baseball history, he holds records for wins (3,731), losses (3,948), and games managed (7,755), with his victory total being almost 1,000 more than any other manager. He managed the Philadelphia Athletics for the club's first 50 seasons of play before retiring at age 87 following the 1950 season. He was the first manager to win the World Series three times, and is the only manager to win consecutive Series on separate occasions (1910-11, 1929-30); his five Series titles remain the third most by any manager, and his nine American League pennants rank second in league history. However, constant financial struggles forced repeated rebuilding of the roster, and Mack's teams also finished in last place 17 times. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornelius_Alexander_McGillicuddy
