Chief Bender‚Äôs warm-up jacket is emblazoned with the Athletics‚Äô elephant logo. At the beginning of the twentieth century, baseball‚Äôs nascent American League, invaded cities with established National League teams. This occurred in Boston, Chicago and Philadelphia and created a ‚Äòturf-war‚Äô between the rival leagues. Many players ‚Äòjumped‚Äô leagues following larger salary offers, fostering a feeling of discontent between principles on both sides. The American League Baltimore franchise pondered a shift in home venue to New York (they would become the Yankees), furthering this simmering dispute. The manager of the National League New York Giants, John McGraw, commented to the press ‚Äúthe Philadelphia club is not making any money. It has a big white elephant on its hands.‚Äù Mr. McGraw‚Äôs pejorative statement of ‚Äúwhite elephant‚Äù implied something odd, worthless and undesirable. Interestingly, Mr. McGraw had just himself ‚Äòjumped‚Äô from the American League Baltimore franchise to the New York National League franchise. Connie Mack, Philadelphia Athletics‚Äô manager, and Ben Shibe the owner of the A‚Äôs defiantly adopted the white elephant as their mascot. The Philadelphia Athletics found success on the field and at the box office; the franchise was anything but a white elephant. The franchise later relocated to Kansas City and then Oakland, the Athletics‚Äô mascot remains an elephant, these days referred to as ‚ÄòStomper.‚Äô

John Franklin "Home Run" Baker (March 13, 1886 - June 28, 1963) was an American third baseman in Major League Baseball from 1908 to 1922. Baker helped the Philadelphia Athletics win three World Series (1910, 1911 and 1913). His legacy has grown over the years and he is regarded by many as the best third baseman of the pre-war era.

Baker, who led the American League in home runs in 1911, earned the nickname "Home Run" during the 1911 World Series in which he hit a go-ahead home run off Rube Marquard in game two and a ninth-inning game-tying home run off Christy Mathewson in game three. His home run crown would be the first of four consecutive seasons leading the American League in home runs. He hit 11 HR in 1911, 10 HR in 1912, 12 HR in 1913, and 9 HR in 1914. Two of those seasons, he also led the American League in runs batted in.

He was born in Trappe, Maryland, was a butcher by trade, and broke into the major leagues in 1908 with the Athletics. Baker played third base for the Athletics until 1915, when he sat out the entire season in a contract dispute. His contract was sold in 1916 to the New York Yankees, with whom he finished his career.

Initially, Baker retired in 1920, but came back to play two more seasons with the Yankees, seasons that took him to two more World Series.

Following his retirement, Baker managed for two seasons (1924-25) in the Eastern Shore Baseball League and was credited with discovering Jimmie Foxx and recommending him to Connie Mack.

He was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1955. In 1981, Lawrence Ritter and Donald Honig included him in their book The 100 Greatest Baseball Players of All Time.

According to the Oct. 15, 1911 edition of the New York Times the Young China Association was located at 12 Mott Street (see link below). According to the article, the flag flying to the left of the US flag was a newly introduced design for the Chinese revolutionary movement. Lucky_dog, Thanks for the information. According to the Oct. 15, 1911 edition of the New York Times the Young China Association was located at 12 Mott Street (see link below). According to the article, the flag flying to the left of the US flag was a new design for the Chinese revolutionary movement. A similar negative in LC‚Äôs Bain Collection is inscribed ‚ÄúNo. 1 10/23/11.‚Äù This negative is inscribed ‚ÄúNo. 2 10/23‚Äù with the year illegible but it is safe to assume that this photo was made in October 1911. As further confirmation of the Mott Street address, the 1915 Brooklyn Daily Eagle Almanac (second link below) indicates that the Morning Star Mission, seen to the right, ran a kindergarten at 10 Mott Street. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9803E... books.google.com/books?id=BBYrAAAAYAAJ&dq=Brooklyn+Da...

and here is another view of this street in 1942 on color film from the Charles W. Cushman photograph collection. webapp1.dlib.indiana.edu/cushman/results/detail.do?query=... in that image, the two red buildings in the center of the photo are No. 10, and 12 Mott St. within 30 years, most of the buildings had their ornamental wrought iron terraces replaced with fire escapes.

Also, noted from about two years before:

US LOC Call Number LC-B22- 344-1A[P&P]

Entitled (erroneously): "Mission house where Elsie Sigel was murdered"

and...

US LOC Call Number LOT 7178 [item] [P&P]  

Entitled (also highly doubtful): "Mission where Elsie Sigel met her slayer, [Chinatown, New York City, New York] Photograph shows exterior view of a building with lodging above the Portland Restaurant "Chinese American chop suey" on the first floor where Elsie Sigel apparently met Leon Ling, a waiter, in Chinatown, New York City, New York."

Both LOC photos are dated 1909 and show the exact same site (one seems to be a crop of the other, with different textual info). However, historically that information contain in the LOC with regards to the Elsie Sigel murder is woefully wrong and should be disregarded. 

*** Sidebar *** Elsie Sigel frequented the mission at 10 Mott Street as a way to rendezvous with Chu Gain (another Chinese man), who was either the owner or manager of the Port Arthur Restaurant (across the street at 9 Mott Street). There is no evidence that the suspect, Leon Ling, ever frequented those locations and evidence was that Miss Sigel was murdered further uptown on 40th streed (almost three miles away). She may have been killed by a jealous Leon Ling when he found out about his rival, Chu Gain. The case caused quite a stir when the public realized that a white woman of good societal standing had freely romanced not just one, but two separate "Chinamen." At the time, Ling was the cause of a nationwide manhunt that resulted in police across the US to capture and detain just about any "Americanized" Asian men in repeated cases of mistaken identity. Ultimately, Ling was never caught, and it is suspected that he had help to leave the country. Some say that help came from those in the Chinese revolutionary movement as he had been, at one point, a member in the "Chinese Empire Reform Association" another sibling political organization with similar aims. Ling was reportedly seen disembarking a tramp steamer in Hong Kong and was never heard from again. The case was never solve.

Viribus Unitis, in Latin meaning "With United Forces", was an Austro-Hungarian Dreadnought built between 1910-1912, and was regarded by many as being a very beautiful warship. The Viribus Unitis had an uneventful career spending most of her time in the port of Pula during the war, and never fired a shot in anger against an enemy ship. The most interesting day in her short life was the day she exploded and sank. Italian frogmen snuck up on her in the middle of the night and planted explosives underneath her. She blew up on the morning of 1 Nov 1918; rolled over and sank upside down in the mud of Pula Harbour. She was later partially scrapped from keel to the main deck, but remains are still in Pula harbour.

The subject is incorrect.
The aircraft shown is classified as an airship not a balloon.

I contacted several experts in airship history. The consensus of opinion is that the aircraft depicted is first British attempt to build a rigid airship. It was called the "Mayfly", official designation HMA-1. The airship never flew on its own although it may have lifted off once while on a tether and did float within the confines of its hangar. It suffered a catastrophic structural failure while on the ground on Sept 24, 1911. References - Hartcup, Guy, "The Achievement of the Airship", David & Charles Inc, 1974, ISBN 7153 6551 7, pp 85-7 www.century-of-flight.net/Aviation history/coming of age/HMA 1 Mayfly.htm NY Times MYSTERIOUS BRITISH AIRSHIP LAUNCHED; Construction of Naval Dirigible Surrounded with Extraordinary Secrecy. May 23, 1911, Tuesday Page 2, 475 words

dannachbar: We've updated the source record to summarize your subject note and correct the subject heading .  With appreciation for your gathering of several sources to confirm the identification and dates!
Could you imagine if we used airships for travel today? How cool would that be!

Following in the footsteps of Count Zeppelin and the success of his early rigid airships, in 1908 the British Government agreed a sum of ¬£35,000 which "should be allocated to the Admiralty for the building of a dirigible balloon". This order to build the first British rigid airship was a direct attempt to compete with the German airship programme.. Statistics: Length 512ft Diameter 46ft Speed 42mph (anticipated) Engines 2 x 180hp Volume 663, 518cft Designs were already being submitted and on 7th May, 1909 the award was given to the Vickers company. The original contract had been for a ship to be constructed for ¬£35,000, however Vickers advised that they could construct the ship for ¬£28,000 without goldbeaters skin gasbags and varnished skin outer cover. The Admiralty would be required to provide contractors for this work. Vickers also asked if they could put up a constructional shed, free of cost to the Crown, so that they may have a ten year monopoly on airship construction as they did with the submarine boat agreement they had with the Crown. On May 7th the contract was awarded, but the 10 year monopoly clause was refused. By 1910 the British Government had committed themselves to a similar path of air-weapon development to that taken by Germany. It was originally planned that the ship be used for scouting capabilities. The project to build the first ship had begun, and designated "HMA No. 1" or more commonly known as "The Mayfly". The design team was working on something that could match the current Zeppelins of the time. These could fly 100 miles, carry a crew of 26, and get to 5,400 feet with an endurance of twelve and a half hours. www.aht.ndirect.co.uk/airships/hma1/index.html

I visited Mount Pleasant Sorting Office  in 1978 or so to see the famous Post Office Underground railway in operation . It linked the main sorting offices with London train stations. In Victorian times it was a pneumatic train, driven by compressed air. In te 1970s it was electric .

The post office was  huge then too hundreds of sorting staff coming and going. Amazing place.

THE FORGOTTEN OF ELLIS ISLAND
Deaths in Quarantine, 1909-1911


A LITTLE ISLAND NEAR NEW YORK PEOPLED WITH BABIES

Taken from Incoming Steamers Suffering from Measles, Scarlet Fever and Other Ills,
They are Cared for on Hoffman Island Till They Get Well.
Source: The New York Times, Magazine Section, November 27, 1910, pages 13+
On a little strip of "made" land, rising midway from the waters of New York Bay, between the Coney and Staten Island shores ‚Äì a strip safeguarded by grim seawalls and barely thirteen acres in extent ‚Äì hundreds of foreigners, almost all women and children, gaze wistfully up the bay toward the city, scarcely visible in the distance, which lured them from their homes across the ocean with promise of work and riches. It is not Ellis Island ‚Äì these particular immigrants have not got as near as that to the goal of their dreams.

The strip of "made" land is Hoffman Island, and the hundreds on it are those taken from incoming ships by Dr. Doty, Health Officer of New York, and his busy assistants at the Quarantine station. Some of these ‚Äì mostly little children ‚Äì have been removed from the ships because of illness; the rest of these on the island are the mothers, brothers, and sisters of these children, who are allowed to remain on the island until their kin get well, and the passengers of incoming ships who have been exposed to infection while in transit and are under observation for signs of disease.

It is only within the last year that Hoffman Island has been so populous. Formerly only those under detention used to sojourn there. But exactly a year ago Dr. Doty put through a plan he had long had in mind - namely, to remove at Quarantine all persons on incoming ships found to have contagious diseases. Previous to the introduction of this rule, the Quarantine officials had jurisdiction only over cases of small pox, yellow fever, typhus fever, bubonic plague, and cholera, which will go to Swinburne Island, Hoffman Island's neighbor, a short distance further down the bay.

It is likely that the caption is correctly oriented in this photograph -- and it is currently displayed on Flickr (and persistent URL) upside down. "Lincoln J. Beachey (March 3, 1887 ‚Äì March 14, 1915), was a pioneer American aviator and early star performer. He was known as The Man Who Owns the Sky, and sometimes the Master Birdman. Acknowledged even by his adversaries as "The World's Greatest Aviator", Beachey achieved the acme of American adoration. Vast crowds followed his tours and it has been estimated that 30 million people saw him in his career, 17 million in 1914 alone (when the US pop. was a mere 74 million). ... "It was at the Panama-Pacific International Exposition [San Francisco] where Beachey made his last flight. Prior to the exposition, in 1914, he ordered a Taube monoplane built with an 80 horsepower (60 kW) engine, powerful enough to carry out the stunt that Beachey had not yet presented to the public: upside-down flight." Beachey was:
* Credited with the invention of Stall recovery * First to fly upside-down * First American to "loop-the-loop" * First to fly inside a building * First to achieve terminal velocity... and live.
(more) -- Wikipedia

"Misturata" is likely a misspelling of "Misurata". (Misurata see Misratah , Libya.) Misratah or Misurata , city, NW Libya, located in an oasis. A seaport on the Mediterranean Sea. Misratah was "In the News" during the 1910's, with the outbreak of The Tripolitanian (Tripolitan) War (also known as the Italo-Turkish or Turco-Italian War, and in Italy as guerra di Libia, "the Libyan war", and in Turkey as Trablusgarp Sava≈üƒ±) on September 29, 1911. An Italian landing at Misratah in October, 1911, made little initial headway. The first ever aerial bomb was dropped on Turkish troops during this war, and may have been dropped on the oasis of Misratah. -- Excerpted from Early Twentieth Century Timelines and Wikipedia.

Wow! Jack Tower (3rd from left) is my Grandfather! I have some pics from his races (and one of a crash at Indy), but I have never seen this one.

He raced in the 1911 Indy 500.
The results:
Fin: 24, St: 23, Car No. 26, Jackson Automobile,

He also raced in the 1913 Indy 500.
The results:
Fin: 19, St: 25, Car No. 6, Mason Motor: Duesenberg. He crashed and  a broken leg. His mechanic (the mechanic rode in the car as well in those days) had broke ribs and internal injuries. I was told he later died, but I'm not sure.

My mother told me he set a speed record in one of the time trials, but I don't have that info.

Anyway, my Grandfather raced, worked with many car companies, and did a test drive across the country at one point. He designed some car features. He also wrote poetry, stories, lyrics, and a bit of music.

He must have been a very interesting man. He passed away, however, before I was born so I never had the pleasure of knowing him.

I just found out recently that my great-great uncle was one of the 78 who died in this awful flood. It was a story I had never heard. It is very tragic to see these photos and know that so many lives were lost.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin_Dam

Austin, a quiet town in Potter County between St. Marys and Coudersport, holds the distinction of having survived the second-worst flood disaster in Pennsylvania's history. On Sept. 30, 1911, at 2:29 in the afternoon, the Bayliss Dam burst. The floodwaters engulfed the town of 2,000 inhabitants, leaving 78 dead and a mass of wreckage in its wake. While the devastation caused by the Johnstown Flood is remembered through films, memorials and museums, the tragedy at Austin faded into obscurity.

He is also referred to as Thomas William Burgess, second person to have swum the English Channel. He was born in Rotherham on June 15, 1872, to Alfred, a blacksmith who came originally from Derbyshire, and Camilla Ann (nee Peat) www.rotherhamweb.co.uk/h/burgess.htm Before his Channel swim, he had taken part in the 1900 Summer Olympics in Paris www.shorpy.com/node/41 He also took part in advertising for Nestle's immediately after his triumph, signing an affidavit that he drank no meat extract (Bovril) during his swim, only drinking Nestles Chocolate and some tea with Nestles milk in it. The swim took 22 hours and 35 minutes, when he was 39 years old,. He also coached Gertrude Erdele who became the first woman to swim the channel on August 6, 1926, and he also advised Edward Temme (1904-1977), who swam from France to England in 1927 and from England to France in 1934.. Thomas William Burgess married a French woman, living with her outside Paris, later moving to Cap Gris Nez near Calais, and he died in 1957, aged 85 www.users.globalnet.co.uk/~westat58/theburgessfamilyo-z.htm

In 1911 Sanford White, at end, scored all the points that brought Princeton its first Big Three title since 1896... Less spectacular, but equally important, was the all-round play at tackle of Eddie Hart, captain in 1910 and 1911. One of the most powerful linemen who ever played for Princeton, he became a legend in the American Expeditionary Force during the First World War when, responding to an offer by a professional strong man in a Paris theatre to take on anyone in the audience, Hart, on orders from his colonel, went forward to the stage and threw the challenger into the wings. In 1911, just before Hart's team was photographed, someone doing research on the rights and privileges of champions discovered John DeWitt in his white sweater. A similar sweater was made ready for Eddie Hart, thus transmuting the 1903 improvisation into tradition. from Princeton Football

The American-born Canadian neurosurgeon, Wilder Graves Penfield (1891-1976), founded and was the first director of the Montreal Neurological Institute. He diagnosed the cause of epilepsy and perfected a surgical cure. Wilder Graves Penfield was born in Spokane, Washington, on January 26, 1891. He was one of three children born to Charles Samuel and Jean (Jefferson) Penfield. His father was a physician and died when Penfield was very young. To support herself and her family, Penfield's mother became a writer and Bible teacher. Penfield spent his early years at the Galahad School in Hudson, Wisconsin, where his mother worked as a housekeeper. Upon graduation in 1909, Penfield was accepted at Princeton University. He was active in extra-curricular activities and became president of his class. He was so good at football, that upon graduation in 1913, he was hired as a coach. After graduation from Princeton with a degree in literature, Penfield held a Rhodes scholarship and a Beit Memorial Research fellowship at Oxford University, where he studied with Sir William Osler and Sir Charles Scott Sherrington. He married Helen Katherine Kermott in 1917 and eventually raised four children. Penfield received his medical degree from Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore in 1918. He worked in Sherrington's research laboratory at Oxford from 1919 to 1921. After his retirement from the Montreal Neurological Institute in 1960, Penfield set out on what he called his "second career" of writing and lecturing around the world. Not one to take to retirement easily, Penfield said " ‚Ä¶ rest is not what the brain needs. Rest destroys the brain." He traveled abroad many times during this period and even lectured in China and Russia. from www.answers.com/topic/wilder-penfield

Negative inscription: "9/5/11 no. 2" So this was before the race, identified elsewhere as being at the Wright Brothers, in Dayton, OH. (see next note). JJ Cole bought a Wright biplane and installed one of his automobile engines for the "Cole Flyer". Here's a little more about the Hearst race: In 1911, the Hearst Transcontinental Flight Derby sponsored a $50,000 prize to the first pilot who completed a transcontinental flight across the United States. The two most noted pilots who attempted this crossing were Calbraith (Cal) P. Rodgers, who took off in his biplane from Sheepshead, New York on September 17, 1911, and Robert C. Fowler, who attempted his flight from the opposite direction, taking off from San Francisco on August 12, 1911, with the hope of reaching Jacksonville, Florida." [Though it seems from Early Aviation's post that Fowler re-started in October) www.banninglibrarydistrict.org/banning/documents/airports... It's likely that the W.L. (William L. Colt) and "H.S."(Harry L.) Stratton pictured were the principals of New York's Colt-Stratton Company, an important auto distributor, and perhaps backers of Fowler's flight. They were in 1912 distributors of the Cole car, and Cole supplied the engine for the plane. books.google.com/books?id=Ibk-N4g_vBgC&pg=RA1-PA264&a... earlyaviators.com/efowler1.htm And J.J. Cole is therefore Joseph J. Cole, the early automaker who produced cars in Indianapolis, Indiana. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cole_Motor_Car_Company At that time, C.P. Henderson was Director and General Sales Manager of Cole Motors. books.google.com/books?id=UzMfAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA487&l... R.P. Henderson, and Homer C. Lathrop were also connected with Cole Motor Car. books.google.com/books?id=uEceAQAAMAAJ&q=lathrop+hend... L.S. French was a Cole executive as well. books.google.com/books?id=-LjhAAAAMAAJ&pg=PP3&lpg...

The date on the photograph is September 17, 1911. This is the day Cal Rodgers took off from Sheepshead Bay, New York at 4:30 pm in pursuit of the Hearst Prize. The Hearst Prize was offered by George Randolph Hearst to the first aviator to fly coast to coast across the United States, in either direction, in fewer than 30 days from start to finish. Rodgers flew a Wright EX Flyer, a modified Model B, named the "Vin Fiz Flyer". Vin Fiz was the sponsor of Rodgers and his airplane. Rodgers would eventually reach Pasadena, California on November 5, 1911, after multiple crashes and mechanical problems throughout his journey. Rodgers would not win the prize because he exceeded the 30 day requirement, and the prize itself had expired weeks earlier. However, Rodgers and the Vin Fiz Flyer would be the first to complete a journey coast to coast across the United States. Calbraith Perry Rodgers earlyaviators.com/erodgers.htm
www.first-to-fly.com/History/History of Airplane/hearstprize.htm

This image had to be between 1910 and 1912...there is no way it could be later than April 3rd of that year. In a flight over Long Beach, Rodgers flew into a flock of sea gulls; his plane crashing into the surf. He perished with a broken neck.

The captioned identity of the aviator in the photo is incorrect, although understandable. It is not Lieutenant "Ellis," but actually Lieutenant Theodore Gordon Ellyson (USN) (b. 1885 - d. 1928). "Spuds" Ellyson was designated "Naval Aviator No. 1". Given the sequence of photos (see the photos of Helene Dutrieu, Earle Ovington, George W. Beatty, Tom Sopwith, etc.), and Ellyson's state of dress, I suspect this photograph was taken at the International Aviation Meet at the Nassau Boulevard Aerodrome on Long Island in September 1911. Here's a flickr photo of Beatty taking off at the meet with Ellyson's hangar in the background: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163726362/sizes/z/in/photostream/] See: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50913FA3D5813738... AIR GAME THRILLS AERODROME CROWD; Toy Balloons Elude World's Greatest Aviators at International Meet Wikipedia's entry on Ellyson: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodore_Gordon_Ellyson Here are a couple of photos of Ellyson from the era posted at the San Diego Air & Space Museum Archives (on flickr) for comparison: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/4728443747/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/4728443309/]

Chick Evans Golf Course is a short yet satisfying 18-hole course located in the northern suburbs of Chicago. The course is named for Chick Evans who in addition to being the first amateur golfer to win both the U.S. Open and the U.S. Amateur Open, founded the Chick Evans Scholarship Program for Caddies. The Chicago River cuts through the center of the course offering beautiful scenery and a formidable obstacle for golfers who play here. Togo Enjoys Day At The Navy Yard. Studies Our Newest and Biggest ... New York Times - Aug 16, 1911 Admiral Count Togo spent a good part of yesterday fraternizing with ... He was the guest of Rear Admiral EHC Leutze, USN, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, ... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T%C5%8Dg%C5%8D_Heihachir%C5%8D Fleet Admiral Marquis (K≈çshaku (‰æØÁàµ k≈çshaku ?)) T≈çg≈ç Heihachir≈ç, OM, GCVO (Êù±ÈÉ∑ Âπ≥ÂÖ´ÈÉé T≈çg≈ç Heihachir≈ç ?), (27 January 1848 - 30 May 1934) was a Fleet Admiral in the Imperial Japanese Navy and one of Japan's greatest naval heroes. He was termed by Western journalists as the 'Nelson of the East'. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eugene_H._C._Leutze Eugene Leutze, son of Emanuel Leutze (1816‚Äì1868), the noted painter of American Revolutionary War scenes, was born in D√ºsseldorf, Prussia, on 16 November 1847. Appointed to the United States Naval Academy by President Abraham Lincoln in 1863, he witnessed part of the Civil War on board the blockade ship Monticello the following summer. His early career brought Leutze various surveying assignments, especially in Central America. In 1897, as commanding officer of Alert, he helped promote the peace when representatives from Costa Rica and Nicaragua met and signed a treaty of peace aboard his ship. As captain of Monterey during the Spanish-American War, he sailed to reinforce Admiral George Dewey‚Äôs fleet at Manila, and was present when the city capitulated. A fine administrator, he was promoted to rear admiral in 1907 while Superintendent of the Naval Gun Factory and Commandant of the Washington Navy Yard, Washington, D.C. Admiral Leutze ended his active career as Commandant of both the 3rd Naval District and the New York Navy Yard on 6 June 1912. He died at Brooklyn Naval Hospital on 1 September 1931. He was interred at Arlington National Cemetery on 6 September 1931 without any "pomp and ritual" at his own request

Melvin Whinfield Sheppard (September 5, 1883 ‚Äì January 4, 1942) was an American athlete, member of the Irish American Athletic Club and winner of four gold medals at the 1908 Summer Olympics and 1912 Summer Olympics. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mel_Sheppard
Grannde...

One of the premiere middle-distance runners of his day.  Sheppard won four golds and one silver medal at the 1908 and 1912 Olympics.  Interestingly, after retiring from competitive running, Sheppard became a lawyer and was one of the defenders of the Lindbergh child kidnapper Bruno Hauptmann.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Eller John Jacob ("Jack" or J.J.) Eller, Jr. (October 15, 1883 ‚Äì January 20, 1967) was born in New Jersey and died in Cutchogue, New York. He was an American track and field athlete, a member of the Irish American Athletic Club and a member of the New York City Police Department from 1905 to 1942. Eller was a five-time Amateur Athletic Union champion in the 220 yard low hurdles between 1907 and 1912. He competed as a member of the U.S. Olympic team in the 1912 Summer Olympics.

Quote below is from Wikipedia en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Maine_(ACR-1) 1911 Court of Inquiry == By 1908, the war drums had long stopped beating, and many parties demanded that the Maine be raised from Havana harbor. Cuban officials became worried about the safety of having a sunken ship in their harbor, U.S. officials wanted the remains of the sailors trapped in the wreck recovered and buried, and a few people wanted to confirm the cause of the sinking. Begun in December 1910, a huge waterproof cofferdam was built around the wreck and water was pumped out, finally exposing the wreck by late summer 1911. Sections of the hull of the Maine were numbered, many photographs were taken, and models of the Maine and her wreckage were built by the single Navy employee assigned to the job in Havana. Except for many souvenir items retained by the Navy and frequently distributed to the public, most of the tangled wreckage was dumped into the sea off the coast of Cuba. Between November 20 and December 2, 1911 a court of inquiry headed by Rear Admiral Charles E. Vreeland visited the wreck. ... After the investigation, the newly located dead were buried in Arlington National Cemetery and the hollow, intact portion of the hull of the Maine was refloated and ceremoniously scuttled at sea on March 16, 1912.

The pinnacle of "Yellow Journalism", the Maine was significant because the major American publications at the time blamed the Spanish for the sinking of the ship (it was later discovered to be the result of a boiler explosion, I believe) without any evidence. It caused a major uproar that eventually led to the Spanish-American war and Teddy Roosevelt's Rough Riders.

This is Rear Admiral Chin Pih Kwang of the Imperial Chinese Navy. On September 14, 1911 the Admiral met President Taft at the President's summer residence in Beverly Mass. On Saturday September 15, 1911 the Admiral made official visits at Governor's Island and at NY City Hall. " ... (He) drove to City Hall to Meet Mayor Gaynor." It was also intended that the Admiral and Mayor Gaynor would visit the tomb of General Grant on Monday September 18. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9900E2DD163CE6... The Rear Admiral's name has also been spelled at "Ching Pih Kwang" Now that I've seen this photograph of Grant's Tomb: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:USA_grants_tomb.jpg I now realise that Rear Admiral Kwang and Mayor Gaynor are staning in from of Grant's Tomb. Therefore the occasion was on Monday September 18, 1911 and is fully described here in the NYT article of the next day: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C07E4DA1131E2... The USS Maine was sunk in Havana Habor on 15 February 1898. In 1910 and 1911 a coffer dam was guiltaround the wreck, and water pumped out thus exposing it. The dead sailors were recovered for later burial at Arlington. Various parts of the wreck were cut up - some became souvenirs, but most of the cutting was done to break up the wreck with the ultimate purpose of making the harbor safe. The barnacle growth seen in the picture makes it likely this pic was taken during this process. www.arlingtoncemetery.net/ussmaine.htm

the reason the Washington is crossed out is this ship was originally the Washington. On 9 November 1916, Washington was renamed Seattle (retaining her classification as Armored Cruiser No. 11). She was simultaneously taken out of reserve and recommissioned for duty as flagship of the Destroyer Force. She was probably renamed as the was a Battleship planned named Washingtn which was later scrapped under the 1922 Naval treaty. her long story is here en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Washington_(ACR-11)

What are the things attached to the gun barrels with leather straps? Would they stay in place when the gun was fired?

I don't think those are leather, I think they are metal claps, they seem to be holding a mirror for the gun layers or sight setters. the rear "rings" are part of the barrel. Here is a very detailed description of how the guns are manufactured www.bobhenneman.info/HeavyGun.htm

The super hi-res version of this image and the others in the Seattle series show stitching on the straps. Metal clamps probably would have damaged the surface of the guns (and they loved these things too much to damage them). 

I thought the barrels were built up with telescoped sections at first, too, but the other images show they're one piece from end to end. The shadows of the straps play tricks on us.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163703598/in/photostream/] 

This image shows the shadows being cast on the opposite side of the straps. 

Every strap can also be followed to a fitting somewhere on the barrel.

isn't it "court martial?"
Thanks for the information!  We‚Äôll look into it.

A Kangaroo Court in this context is an informal or mock court usually performed by your peers for infractions. For example, if you are on a sports team and forget a piece of equipment the kangaroo court may punish you by making you buy a round of beers. It is generally considered a form of hazing. In the picture I can speculate that perhaps the young sailor showed up late for muster and is being publicly ridiculed. Maybe he will be punished by swabbing the deck. Based on body language, smiles of the audience, and informality this is clearly not a real Court Martial.
If it were real, he'd have to walk the plank . . . .

I once witnessed a pretty unpleasant 'Kangaroo Courts Martial' when a young sailor who was very dirty and did'nt wash as much as he should was dealt with by his peers.
He was stripped, thrown into a bath of freezing cold water, the bath then having every bit of rubbish that could be found thrown into it and he was then scrubbed with long handled deck scubbers till he bled.
It did the trick, that chap just about lived in the showers for a long time after that.
One of the first things I learnt in the navy was this... "Cleanliness comes next to Godliness, and if you can't be Godly then by God you can be clean!"
Any old Navy man will recognise that this is not a sailors yarn.

Going to pray at St. Jean Baptiste:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163705706/in/photostream/]

St. Jean Baptiste Catholic Church is on Lexington Avenue on New York City's Upper East Side. It is a large stone structure built in the early 20th century for a congregation formed in 1882 to serve the area's French Canadian immigrant population. Financier Thomas Fortune Ryan, a Catholic convert in his teens, bankrolled its construction. The Italian architect practicing in New York Nicholas Serracino, who combined elements of the Italian Renaissance Revival and Classical Revival architectural styles, won won first prize for the design at the Esposizione Internazionale delle Industrie e del Lavore in Turin, in 1911. It is his only surviving church in the city. It is one of the few Catholic churches in New York City with a dome, and only one of two ‚Äî the other being St. Patrick's Cathedral ‚Äî with stained glass windows from the glass studios of Chartres. The building was designated a city landmark in 1969. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1980 along with its rectory.[1] In the late 20th century the interior and exterior were both restored. Started in 1882 in a rented hall above a stable, the congregation has been through three buildings at two locations. St. Jean Baptiste High School was started on the grounds as an elementary school by nuns of the Congregation of Notre Dame in 1886. In the late 19th century an exposure by a visiting priest of a relic of St. Anne intended for one night, grew into a three-week event during which many miracle cures were alleged by thousands of pilgrims who crowded the church; as a result the church now has its own shrine to the saint, which led to a failed effort to get it designated a basilica. In 1900 it passed from the control of the founding Fathers of Mercy to the Congregation of the Blessed Sacrament, who introduced Eucharistic adoration as a worship style. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Jean_Baptiste_Catholic_Church

The date would suggest it was 23 June 1911 which was one day after the Coronation of King George V. Since this is almost certainly a picture of the Coronation procession I would think the date refered to the day it was processed or published. Many other copies of this and other pictures in the series are available on the Internet, all taken from the same position but with the procession moved.
This is the Royal Procession which takes place on the day following the coronation.
The carriage appears to contain a Maharaja and the following cavalry is Indian.

Review of NYTimes articles shows a few mentions around the 4th of July of several games in New York and Chicago. The Waseda Baseball Team website's history page says this was their second tour of the US, and ended 17 victories, 36 losses, one cancellation (forfeit?). The trip lasted from March 28th until August 17th. Brief article on Japan baseball history, describing book "Through a Diamond". Baseball was controversial in Japan at the time. In August when the Waseda team returned, an historic editorial was printed by Nitobe Inazo, comparing baseball's deceipt to picking pockets. (He preferred the manliness and honesty of rugby)

This photo is discussed in The Commons research thread. When I was digging around, I found that there were only a few (college) teams in Japan, so they often hosted international teams and traveled to play. I'd like to understand exactly how this counted as school credit... were they really learning English? Touring businesses and factories?

Togo arrived from Liverpool on the Lusitania.  It arrived late in the evening on Thursday, August 3rd, 1911, which would explain the reason for the night shot with no background scenery.  New York Times on August 5th says that Togo went to bed in his room at Hotel Knickerbocker at 2am Friday, August 4th, 1911.

Full schedule of Togo's tour of the US is in an August 2nd, 1911 NYTimes article.

Son of the famous Confederate Civil War General who also was a U. S. General in the Spanish-American War (and served numerous terms in Congress).

From the Wikipedia biography of his father:

Joseph Jr.

The first son, Joe Jr. was born in 1872. He attended West Point and graduated in 1895. He joined the Army and was stationed at the Washington Barracks D.C.. After training at the Artillery School at Ft. Monroe in Virginia. Joe Jr. then was a Mathematics instructor at West Point before the Spanish-American War broke out. At the start of the War Joe Jr. was made an aide on his father's staff and sailed for Cuba on June 1898. The following year he was made a Major of the 34th infantry, US volunteers and left in September 1899 for the Philippines. He served in many different areas after this, finally retiring in February 1927. He died 6 August 1938.

The system, based on the classification of skeletal and other body measurements and characteristics, was officially adopted in France in 1888 and soon after in other countries. Fingerprinting, added later as a supplementary measure, has largely replaced the system

anyone read French and know what this is about?

It says 'Formulaire du portrait parl√©'. Portrait parl√©, aka Bertillon system, first scientific method of criminal identification, developed by the French criminologist Alphonse Bertillon (1853-1914). The system, based on the classification of skeletal and other body measurements and characteristics, was officially adopted in France in 1888 and soon after in other countries. Fingerprinting, added later as a supplementary measure, has largely replaced the system
THANKS.  Was it a racist thing?

No, it wasn't a racist thing.  It was an attempt to identify people uniquely, the same way that fingerprints do.  Instead of being fingerprinted, arrested criminals were measured in a number of specific ways, on the theory that that combination of measurements was unique to them.

It failed mostly because it required a lot of training to get the measurements right, and because fingerprinting came in shortly after it was invented.  It also had the disadvantage that it wasn't usable in all the ways a fingerprint is.  No one leaves a complete set of Bertillon measurements at a crime scene!
Thanks for the clarification.

Liste des abr√©viations les plus usit√©es = List of the most used abbreviations
Formulaire du portrait parl√© = Form for the spoken portrait 
Tableau synoptique des formes de nez = Synoptic table of the shapes of noses
Combinaison des dimensions de nez = Combinaison of the (different) lengths of noses

Alphonse Bertillon (April 24, 1853 ‚Äì February 13, 1914) was a French police officer and biometrics researcher who created anthropometry, an identification system based on physical measurements. Anthropometry was the first scientific system used by police to identify criminals. Before that time, criminals could only be identified based on unreliable eyewitness accounts. The method was eventually supplanted by fingerprinting, but "his other contributions like the mug shot and the systematisation of crime-scene photography remain in place to this day." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphonse_Bertillon

The inscribed date on the photo (reversed) reads "9/13/11" (albeit with a poorly inscribed "3").  This dates the photo to September 13, 1911, the day Jimmie Ward took off from Governors Island in his Curtiss Pusher (named "Hearst Pathfinder") in pursuit of the William Randolph Hearst Prize, a $50,000 prize to the first aviator to complete a transcontinental flight of the United States within 30 days by October 11, 1911.  Ward's aircraft would suffer an engine failure a three days after this photo.  After repairs, Ward would continue his journey, but would be forced to withdraw after his aircraft was wrecked beyond repair (again, after an engine failure and crash landing) on September 22, 1911.

This picture together with LC-B2- 2265-8 (Ward and Hudson Maxim) and LC-B2- 2265-9 Ward in his Curtiss airplane) and LC-B2- 2265-5 (Ward taking off from Grosvenor Island New York) all belong together. Pictures were taken on the occasion of the start of the aviator James J. Ward for the Hearst Transcontinental Flight, where he would fly the traject New York - San Francisco. The first who did the transcontinental flight earned the prize allotted by Hearst: $ 50,000. The start in New York of Ward was on September 13, 1911 where he left at 09:00 hours. So the pictures can be exactly dated. According to the record two man in high places were present Major-General Grant (probably 'another' Grant) and Hudson Maxim (the brother of Hiram Maxim, Hudson Maxim was also an inventor). Remarkable is the take off picture which was exactly taken when Ward got the machine loose from the ground. In the background is the Statue of Liberty. As told Ward came not very far and he abandoned his prize flight around the 22nd of September 1911. The whole occassion was reported on in the NY Times September 13, 1911 and following. The report of the start (giving also the names of Major-General Grant and Hudson Maxim) can be found at query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9402E0D91531E2... with the title 'Ward on long flight. Will start from Governors Island Today on a Trip to San Francisco'. Cheers Kees

Aviator Jimmie Ward is the helmeted figure in the photo.  This photo was taken on September 13, 1911, the day Ward took off from Governors Island in his Curtiss Pusher biplane (named the "Hearst Pathfinder") as he began his attempt to win the William Randolph Hearst Prize. Otherwise known as the "Hearst Transcontinental Prize" or "Hearst Prize", $50,000 was offered by William Randolph Hearst in October 1910 to the first aviator to complete a transcontinental flight across the United States in less than 30 days, no later than October 11, 1911. Jimmie Ward would withdraw from the race nine days later after his aircraft's engine failed, causing it to crash land just west of Addison, New York, suffering damage beyond repair.

TVL 1970: This race was certainly an amazing event and the date agrees with the date on the negative.  Thanks for identifying Jimmy Ward. Do you have any information about why Frederick Grant was there?

Can't say I have any information as to why Gen. Grant was there, other than to surmise that the island was a military reservation, Grant was commander of the Eastern Division of the Army, and Eastern Division Headquarters was located at Ft. Jay (the Army facility on Governors Island) at the time.

That is aviator James J. "Jimmie" Ward (born in Denmark as Jens P. Wilson, b. 1886 - d. December 3, 1923) taking off from Governors Island in his Curtiss Pusher biplane (a Curtiss Model D named the "Hearst Pathfinder") on September 13, 1911, as he started his attempt to win the William Randolph Hearst Prize.  Otherwise known as the "Hearst Transcontinental Prize" or "Hearst Prize",  $50,000 was offered by William Randolph Hearst in October 1910 to the first aviator to complete a transcontinental flight across the United States in less than 30 days, no later than October 11, 1911.  Jimmie Ward would withdraw from the race nine days later after his aircraft's engine failed, causing it to crash land just west of Addison, New York, suffering damage beyond repair. 

 Cal Rodgers in his Wright Model EX "Vin Fiz" would also compete for the prize, becoming the first person to complete a transcontinental flight across the United States.  However, Rodgers would fail to win the Hearst Prize because his journey lasted 49 days (September 13-November 5, 1911)

In 1911, Earle Ovington earned the distinction of becoming America's first airmail pilot.
Long Island, New York, has a road named for him: Earle Ovington Boulevard.

Wikipedia tells the story:
"Earle Lewis Ovington (December 20, 1879 - July 21, 1936) was an American aeronautical engineer, aviator and inventor, and served as a lab assistant to Thomas Edison. Ovington piloted the first official airmail flight in the United States in a Bl√©riot XI [on September 23,] 1911. He carried a sack of mail from Garden City, New York to Mineola, New York. He circled at 500 feet and tossed the bag over the side of the cockpit and the sack burst on impact, scattering letters and postcards. He delivered 640 letters and 1,280 postcards, including a letter to himself from the United States [Post Office] designating him as 'Official Air Mail Pilot #1.'"

The Smithsonian has posted a photo of Ovington in his Bleriot monoplane, with the mail pouch: www.centennialofflight.gov/essay/Government_Role/Pre-1918... More photos of Ovington have been posted on Flickr, by the San Diego Air and Space Museum: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/5020853395/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/4815247549/]

A Bain/LOC photo shows Ovington receiving the sack of mail from the Postmaster General of the United States, Frank Harris Hitchcock. Hitchcock had expected to be a passenger on this symbolic, three-mile flight, and was disappointed when Ovington showed up with a single-seater Bleriot monoplane. Hitchcock almost called off the flight until a two-seat plane could be arranged, but was persuaded to press on, regardless.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2162926957/]

Earle Ovington never received a license from the Aero Club of America. Ovington obtained his license from the Aero Club of France, Pilot # 440  March 3, 1911
The Ovington airmail flights were conducted from the Nassau Boulevard Aerodrome, Garden City , Long Island, New York. This airfield existed only 1911-1912

The CAMPANIA was a ship of the Cunard line. She was pulled into the Royal Navy during WW1 and was converted into Britain's first aircraft carrier.She sank of the Firth Of Forth in 1918, after a collision with HMS REVENGE. Pictures of the conversion here: www.seayourhistory.org.uk/component/option,com_gallery2/I...
Here is a NY Times article dated 1914. You can sign up for a free account, if you don't have one. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9500EFDA1730E7...

not just any ship either, Campania was the largest and fastest passenger liner afloat when she entered service in 1893. She crossed the Atlantic in less than six days; and on her second voyage in 1893, she won the prestigious Blue Riband, previously held by the Inman Liner SS City of Paris, losing it the following year to her identical sister, Lucania.

Please reconsider retitling this photo to spell out Japanese. The abbreviation chosen is offensive to many and reverts to the dismissive terminology used during WWII and is out of place in this day and age. -- Seen on your photo stream. (?)

Thanks for understanding that no offense is intended. We retain the original title of a photograph as part of preserving the historical record. The Bain News Service photo titles are available from several sources‚Äîtyped in the set of caption cards consulted while making the scans, hand-written on an older set of cards, and etched on the negatives themselves. In this case, the abbreviated term is the only form found.

Sorry, but I do not understand the need to title the photo by what is marked on the photo itself. The photo stands by itself and there is no need to carry the offensive abbreviation to the title. The title of the photo cannot be excused by the claim that it merely reflects what is written on the photo itself, as the choice of title is the free choice of the poster, the Library of Congress, and as such reflects the Library of Congress' own voice. Is it not the Library of Congress' own voice when titling a photo that contains no textual markings? Does it not reflect the best judgment of the Library of Congress regarding the presumed factual (and not editorial) content of the photo? And what if extensive study shows that there exists photos in the collection that is marked in error with incorrect information? Would you in fact title the photo with the incorrect information? I suspect not, as it would be assumed that unless otherwise explicitly stated that the title is written in the voice of the Library of Congress. And are your methods such that any offensive comment written on a photo in your archives will also carry the same title on Flickr? And what is one to make of this photo, where a selective correction to the hand-written note was made when composing its title? Perhaps there can be a reasonable compromise. There exists photos in your collection that makes a clear distinction between the Library of Congress' voice and that of whoever annotated the photo, with square brackets used to mark the poster's (Library of Congress') voice. Perhaps that could be used in this case. e.g.: "[Japanese] typhoon-boats washed a mile inland at Tokyo (LOC)" Please reconsider retitling this photo. To use such racially loaded and derogatory abbreviations in an area that many would interpret as the Library of Congress' own voice is a very unwise choice and is not fitting the character of such a fine institution. Though I have not viewed all of your photos I have browsed through many of them and nowhere else do I see a similar offense committed. This is a bad precedent to set and is all the more unusual and provocative in its uniqueness with respect to the rest of your collection.

@cgfan: LC should probably retitle with brackets as you suggest to simply avoid the debate.  It's historically significant that over the life of the boot black photo, some librarian at LC has mapped "Jew" to "Jewish" (possibly taking offense?), but the same hasn't happened for this photo.  Taking the abberviation out of the limelight of the index title, and storing it in a longer descriptive entry seems like the right move now.  Editing this stuff is a slippery slope, but to my ears "Jew" is more legit than "Jap".

Contrary to your claim, though, there are textual markings on the photo.  The text ("titling" as you refer to it alternately) was scrawled on by an observer of the events (photographer), which makes it primary source material and just as legitimate historic evidence as the photo itself.  What if a researcher is tracking the history of the use of the phrase "Jap"?  Erasing it from the digital database will simply hide the widespread nature of this term, and perhaps its start as an innocuous abbreviation for a long word.  This photo is almost three decades before the climax of the racist term.  It needs to be accessible somewhere.

roketpad: Thank you for adding your comments.  Sounds like we are both in agreement regarding my suggestion as to how to possibly settle the current debate.

However I don't see this as the "slippery slope" you mention in the closing of your first paragraph.  The title given right now on Flickr should relect the LOC's current voice.  If they wish to use racial epithets, than so be it, keep the title, but I doubt this represents their voice, and if not, it should be changed.

By no means does the LOC's changing a Flickr title impact the historical record, which is clear in the photo.  If there were no handwriting on the photo at all, then wouldn't the word's chosen by the LOC to title the Flickr photo be in the LOC's voice too?  Now just because the LOC agreed with the scribe's handwritten note regarding the factual content of the photo does not in turn obligate the LOC to repeat verbatim the scribe's words.  The LOC should use whatever words they feel are necessary to describe the photo.  Whatever words they use to title the photo today is part of the historical record of not the original scribe's voice, but of the LOC's.

Your comments gave us good food for thought! Expanding an abbreviated word in a title to clarify a spelling can be helpful, so we‚Äôve added the fuller spelling in brackets. But this kind of bracketed interpolation is not intended to replace original vocabulary even when a word can cause offense. Quoting an original title is part of preserving historical context by reflecting how an item presented itself when first produced. Just as the Library doesn‚Äôt re-title books or movies, we don‚Äôt re-title pictures that come to us with formal titles. The unbracketed titles that appear with Library of Congress images in Flickr are not the Library‚Äôs own voice. The titles are transcriptions of original text found with the historical photographs. If putting ‚Äú(LOC)‚Äù at the ends of the titles is creating the impression that the Library is writing a new title, we need to rethink adding that indication of where the photo is from. (When a photograph lacks an original title, then a note is provided ‚ÄúTitle devised by Library staff‚Äù and brackets appear around the entire title. There are also judgment calls when, for example, only a surname or multiple abbreviated words appear on a photo. In those cases, the photo may have been given a quick annotation rather than a formal title, and a descriptive title might be devised with an explanatory note about the title source.) Your comments are helpful for seeing that in the complicated situation with the Bain negatives, where there are multiple sources of historical caption information (two sets of cards and the negatives themselves), varying the title source can cause confusion. Especially when our source of title notes ambiguously cite multiple sources as: ‚ÄúTitle from unverified data provided by the Bain News Service on the negatives or caption cards.‚Äù We‚Äôd better stick with a single source-what can be seen in the negative. We‚Äôve started by making sure that the titles for the photos mentioned in the comments above match what‚Äôs written on the negatives rather than the caption cards. FYI, the published standard that guides our practice in describing the variety of pictures we preserve is called "Graphic Materials: Rules for Describing Original Items and Historical Collections." It's available online at www.loc.gov/rr/print/gm/graphmat.html.

Please reconsider retitling this photo to spell out Japanese. The abbreviation chosen is offensive to many and reverts to the dismissive terminology used during WWII and is out of place in this day and age. -- Seen on your photo stream. (?)

Thanks for understanding that no offense is intended. We retain the original title of a photograph as part of preserving the historical record. The Bain News Service photo titles are available from several sources‚Äîtyped in the set of caption cards consulted while making the scans, hand-written on an older set of cards, and etched on the negatives themselves. Abbreviated spellings are common, and in this case, the sources all abbreviate the word Japanese.

Sorry, but I do not understand the need to title the photo by what is marked on the photo itself. The photo stands by itself and there is no need to carry the offensive abbreviation to the title. The title of the photo cannot be excused by the claim that it merely reflects what is written on the photo itself, as the choice of title is the free choice of the poster, the Library of Congress, and as such reflects the Library of Congress' own voice. Is it not the Library of Congress' own voice when titling a photo that contains no textual markings? Does it not reflect the best judgment of the Library of Congress regarding the presumed factual (and not editorial) content of the photo? And what if extensive study shows that there exists photos in the collection that is marked in error with incorrect information? Would you in fact title the photo with the incorrect information? I suspect not, as it would be assumed that unless otherwise explicitly stated that the title is written in the voice of the Library of Congress. And are your methods such that any offensive comment written on a photo in your archives will also carry the same title on Flickr? And what is one to make of this photo, where a selective correction to the hand-written note was made when composing its title? Perhaps there can be a reasonable compromise. There exists photos in your collection that makes a clear distinction between the Library of Congress' voice and that of whoever annotated the photo, with square brackets used to mark the poster's (Library of Congress') voice. Perhaps that could be used in this case. e.g.: "[Japanese] typhoon-boats washed a mile inland at Tokyo (LOC)" Please reconsider retitling this photo. To use such racially loaded and derogatory abbreviations in an area that many would interpret as the Library of Congress' own voice is a very unwise choice and is not fitting the character of such a fine institution. Though I have not viewed all of your photos I have browsed through many of them and nowhere else do I see a similar offense committed. This is a bad precedent to set and is all the more unusual and provocative in its uniqueness with respect to the rest of your collection.

Carl : Its definitely not the LNWR Loco in your photo - 2-4-0 "Hardwicke" on the turntable, at NRM (National Railway Museum, York, UK). Nice photo though, this loco is very difficult to photo unless the light conditions are exactly right in the Great Hall (old roundhouse). Looking at the running board and splasher designs. The running board has 2 large cut outs, and 2 small ones. The splasher shows the name and you can just make out at least the first letter "A"......; the number 1395 is visible. 'On earlier British locomotives the tops of the wheels usually projected through slots in the running plate and were covered by "splashers" which are analogous to mudguards on a road vehicle.' (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Footplate) It is definately a compound (3rd cylinder), and most likely a 2-2-2-0 "Dreadnought", as cited above by Stephen Rees. You can just see the top of the LH cylinder below the running board, ahead of the splasher. (See LNWR Society data pages : 'Dreadnaught' class and 'Raven' for comparisons ). Possibly there were some renumberings, before scrappings, given this photo shows #1395? Given that the LNWR was amalgamated into the LMS in 1922, ahead of the railway groupings of 1923, there is no signing of any LMS style anywhere in the photo. The Clerestory coach on the track alongside also looks as if it is LNWR livery. The first coach is almost certainly a travelling post office vehicle, with an offset corridor connection, and the rest look similar but with no ducket (lookout). So this is clearly a mail train.

Note the distinctive Trade Union banners.  Also there is a band playing on the left of the picture.
Most likely the General Strike of 1926, since another picture in this series is dated May 1926.

The first banner is for the Stepney branch of the "London Carmen." They were one of the primary unions involved in the August 1911 dock strike. According to 'A Summary Description of the Papers of National Union of Vehicle Workers' at www.warwick.ac.uk/services/library/mrc/ead/126vwcol.htm 'The National Union of Vehicle Workers was formed as the London Carmen's Trade Union in 1888. By 1892 the union's membership had declined from an initial figure of 6,000 to 2,000. The membership of the union rose again in the period 1895-1910. The London Carmen's Trade Union originally represented carters of East End traffic to and from docks and warehouses. The union had a tradition of collaboration with other unions and in 1911 delegates were sent to the first General Council meeting of the National Transport Workers' Federation. The General Secretary of the union, Sam March, sat on the Executive Council of the National Transport Workers' Federation. The London Carmen's Trade Union was strongly influenced by syndicalism and its members were prominent in the 1911 strikes in London. The failure of the 1912 London transport workers' strikes however resulted in a significant loss of membership from 8,000 members in the union to half that number in 1913. In the same year the union changed its name to the National Union of Vehicle Workers (NUVW) . The NUVW was one of the founding members of the Transport and General Workers' Union and played a significant role in bringing road haulage workers into the new union.' The TGWU was formed in 1922. So I think THIS picture is more likely to be from 1911 than 1926.
Agreed. To the right of the bridge, there now stands a much larger building, Adelaide House, built in 1924-5.

Thomas Clark Bundy (October 8, 1881 ‚Äì October 13, 1945) was a tennis player from the Los Angeles, California, United States. Bundy won the All-Comers final, but finished runner-up to William Larned in the Challenge Round of the U.S. National Championships men's singles event, in 1910. Bundy took consecutive three men's doubles titles at the tournament, alongside Maurice McLoughlin, in 1912, 1913, and 1914.[1] He married tennis player U.S. National Championships and Wimbledon champion May Sutton in 1912, and is the father of 1938 Australian Championships winner Dorothy Cheney. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Bundy

Is it possible this was really 1917? The Wikipedia Japanese typhoon page lists October 1, 1917 as the only memorable typhoon from the 1910s. It hit Tokyo Bay directly, and 3000 people died. Meiji Maru was tied up at the (predecessor to) the Tokyo University of Marine Science and Technology at this time, and used for training. A history of the ship on the university's site mentions that the bowsprit was broken in 1917 during the typhoon. Unfortunately this is an aft photo. [edit: fixed a URL; Kaiyodai changed it]

Still trying to figure out when this was, and learning how to research typhoons online :P The 1910s were a bad decade for typhoons in Japan, despite Wikipedia's lonely mention (surprise!). 1917 still seems like the most likely candidate, with a storm surge that was so huge that it is referred to as a tsunami (tidal wave, caused by earthquake). It would take something significant to lift all of the ships up onto land. This photo is part of a series depicting beached ships and boats. Other possibilities: 1910, 1911, 1914. Sources: Review of photo collection held by Tokyo Fire Department. Singles out 1917 but also mentions August 1910 and July 1911 as particularly bad storms. History of Tama River. The Great Tsunami of Taisho Year 6, part of the series "Fighting Disaster". Includes an excerpt from a paper describing a ship up against JR Tsudanuma station in the 1917 typhoon, which like the maritime academy is on the north shore of Tokyo Bay. Missionary Review of the World, which discusses the damage to St. Luke's Hospital in the 1917 typhoon. St. Luke's is on the other side of Tsukishima at the mouth of the Sumida River from the maritime academy where the Meiji Maru was docked. List of major natural disasters in history mentions the 1917 typhoon but no other for the 1910s in the Tokyo area. Another list of major natural disasters includes 1911 and 1914 as well as 1917 for the Tokyo area.
This photo is discussed in The Commons research thread. If my assumption that it was tied up at home was correct, the merchant marine academy is here.

An article from August 2024 about a visit to the ship - japan.stripes.com/travel/meiji-maru-and-monjayaki-tokyo%E... indicates that the ship is in reasonable shape and can be visited, but is not open every day. Both cars have the same licence plate number. Is it possible that all the cars of Taft's fleet had the same plates?

I think I found the answer.  (Is there anything that can't be Googled?)  By the auto registration laws of those days, dealers could apply for one registration for their entire fleet and then get duplicate plates of the registration number for all their cars.  (I tried to make a tinyurl of the "McKinney's Consolidated Laws" Googlebook website but Flickr won't post it.)

I'd guess that Taft took the train to NYC, and a local dealer supplied the cars for his motorcade.  Can you tell the model?  There's a logo on the lead car's grille, but it's hidden by the license plate.

Nice work rjones0856! Both vehicles are White steam cars, made in Cleveland. Taft apparently chose the White steamer as the official state car for himself and his staff. Just coincidence that he lived in the White House at the time!
Also a coincidence that Taft was from Ohio, where the cars were built.

The caption on the print is incorrect. On the right side of the photo is seated famed early aviator J. Clifford Turpin in what is likely a Wright Model B aircraft. "Lieut. Rogers" is actually at the controls on the left side of the photo and is likely Lieutenant John Rodgers (US Naval Aviator #2). Rodgers was trained at the Wright School of Aviation in 1911 and flew from Huffman Prairie in Dayton, Ohio at the same time Cliff Turpin was a Wright Company pilot and instructor. While Rodgers was training at Huffman Prairie, he was visited by his cousin Calbraith "Cal" Perry Rodgers. Cal Rodgers became interested in aviation and he himself was instructed by the Wright Company and purchased his own aircraft. Cal Rodgers would become the first aviator to fly from coast to coast (Sept. 17 to Nov. 11, 1911) in a Wright Model EX Flyer named the "Vin Fiz". Cal Rodgers would perish in a plane crash during an exhibition flight over Long Beach, California in April 1912. Lt. John Rodgers would become Commander John Rodgers. Rodgers perished in 1926 when the aircraft he was piloting plunged into the Delaware River. Six ships were named in honor of him, his great-grandfather (Commodore John Rodgers) and grandfather (Admiral John Rodgers) ‚Äì USS Rodgers and USS John Rodgers (DD-574, DD-983). John Rodgers Airport (now Honolulu International Airport, HNL) was also named after him (from Wikipedia). More here: hawaii.gov/hawaiiaviation/hawaii-aviation-pioneers/john-r...
Thanks for the information TVL 1970.  We'll correct the names next time we update the record.

What makes this picture special and rare is that it's showing Andrew Carnegie's full body in direct comparison to others. Carnegie was short and wore high hats and shoes to hide this. David Nasaw writes in his great Carnegie biography about how he would rarely allow to be shot standing and almost never standing next to others so as to not give a hint as to his lack of height. he doesn't seem to be bothered by this shot, making this all the more interesting to me.

The photo was taken in Manhattanville (West Harlem). The photo shows the aftermath of a burst water main on West 129th Street just east of the crossing at Broadway which occurred on June 23rd, so the photo was probably taken later that month. The NY Times reported ("Flood Rages In Manhattan Valley," June 24, 1911) the loss of 3,000,000 gallons of water from the "city's dwindling supply" and $10- to $15,000 in property damage. The vertical girder to the left holds up the elevated section of the Manhattan Street subway station -- renamed 125th Street Station in 1921 -- of today's #1 line. The front of the white Sheffield Farms building in the central background (built in 1908, and known today as Columbia University's Prentis Hall) is obscured by a frame structure on the triangular block where area locals will recall the Floridita Cuban Restaurant was located until recently and where a gas station is still in operation. To learn more about this fascinating old NYC neighborhood, see my book, "Manhattanville: Old Heart of West Harlem." Thank you LOC for sharing this pic, which I'd never seen, although I immediately recognized the event.

Thank you, Eric, for your synopsis of the event and details about the neighborhood.  We'll fill in the caption information and date the next time we update the record.  I hope that you will continue to browse our images and share your research.  Your book sounds fascinating.

The Princess Anne was an Old Dominion steamship running between Norfolk, VA and NYC for many years. She was launched at Chester, PA on May 1, 1897 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0CEFDD1630E132A... See also Chesapeake Steamers, Page 35 books.google.com/books?id=UUnMTCDT0ZsC According to the Medical Record V52, 1897, page 762 in a list of resorts.. books.google.com/books?id=0BcCAAAAYAAJ 'Old Point Comfort and Virginia Beach, as well as Norfolk, are accessible from New York by the Old Dominion Steamship Company's line. Fares from New York to Old Point, $8; round trip, $13. The same to Norfolk. To Virginia Beach, $8.50; round trip, $13.50. Hotel rates, $3 to $5 per day. The Old Dominion line dispatches one of its comfortable and commodious ocean-going steamers every week day for these Virginia ports, and the night at sea generally proves a delightful break in the journey.' The trip was clearly popular. The steamship was one of four that Old Dominion Line extended (or at least planned to) by cutting in half and welding in a forty-two foot section in the middle -- to carry more passengers. CUTTING A FLEET IN TWO December 17, 1905, Sunday query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9403E4DB153AE733A... However, the journey was not always trouble-free: PANIC ON THE PRINCESS ANNE.; Old Dominion Liner Reaches Port Ten Hours Late After Hard Battle Against the Storm. September 17, 1903, Thursday query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F01E7DC173AE733A... JAMES T. SCHEUER DEAD.; New Yorker Disappeared from Old Dominion Liner. January 28, 1909, Thursday query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A01EEDD153EE733A... PRINCESS ANNE RENT ASUNDER MID PANIC; Officers' Pistols Quiet Crew When Plates Snap--Men Taken Off Later. VESSEL IS A TOTAL LOSS Hope Abandoned for Ship Flooded Below Main Deck--May Salvage Cargo. Pistols Quiet the Crew. Rescue Ship Near Disaster. February 10, 1920, Tuesday query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A06EFD6133BEE32A... During the 1910-1915 period, the NYT suggests a couple of options for newsworthy events involving the Princess Anne that might help date the photo. One possibility is 'the southern mobilization effort' LIKE REAL WARTIME AS LOCAL TROOPS GO; 1,450 Coast Artillerymen Off in a Hurry for Galveston Via Fort Monroe. March 9, 1911, Thursday query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0CE0DD1439E333A... Troops were setting off from NYC for Galveston via Fort Monroe (Hampton, VA) on the Old Dominion liner Jamestown. The Princess Anne was loaded up with supplies for the same journey. See also 'Troops arriving in Galveston' in what looks like a passenger liner rather than a naval ship www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163503938/ [Aside: The article above also mentions marines heading to Philadelphia to embark on the Prairie for Cuba. Could be connected to: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2162704503 www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163505442] Later that year, she brought to NYC the crew and some of the passengers from a liner sunk off Cape Charles, VA. and given the direct connection to flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163461266/ this seems the most likely date for the picture. MERIDA PASSENGERS TELL OF HER LOSS; The Princess Anne Brings Crew and Travelers Saved from Sinking Ward Liner. May 14, 1911, Sunday query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0CEFDD1E3EE033A... But she kept on cropping up in the news... NYT March 13, 1915, Saturday query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9502E4DA1539E333A... 'The crews of four ships that had been sunk by the German auxiliary cruiser Prinz Eitel Friedrich, arrived here yesterday afternoon by the Old Dominion Line steamship Princess Anne, on their way home to France and Russia.' Her wreck after running aground off Rockaway Point in February 1920 (see NYT citation above) is now familiar to divers. See www.aquaexplorers.com/PrincessAnne.htm. This page gives 1930 as the wreck date, instead of 1920 (which is from the NYT article).

This is likely the home of John Hayes Hammond (portrait). The 1910-1915 D.C. city directories list him as having two different addresses during those years, 1500 Rhode Island Ave., NW and 2315 Massachusetts Ave., NW (the latter since demolished, the former still standing but renovated beyond recognition, now occupied by the National Paint and Coatings Association).

Having looked at a few photos, I'm thinking this is likely 1500 Rhode Island Avenue, NW - Robert Bruce reports in Alexander Graham Bell and the Conquest of Solitude that John Hayes Hammond rented 1500 at one point. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Highland_Fling "The Highland Fling is one of the oldest of the traditional Highland dances of Scotland. Returning from a victorious battle, male warriors would perform the dance in celebration of their success.... This dance is now performed at dance competitions and events around the world. It is no longer danced on a shield, but it is still the goal of the dancer to stay in the same spot throughout the dance. The Highland Fling is danced at almost all competition levels, from Primary to Premier. It is also performed for most Highland and Theory examinations. Dancers wear the standard Kilt outfit to perform this dance."

This was taken in front of the original Colony Club Building (1904-1908) at 120 Madison Avenue in New York City. The Colony Club moved uptown, but the building's still there, and today used by the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. The AIA Guide to New York City notes that its architect, the renowned Stanford White, was assassinated during its construction only three blocks away. You can read a great New York Times article about the building here.

Mrs. Loew could well afford to indulge her whims in Bronx Park. She was an heiress; her father had left her 5 million. Her husband, William, was a stockbroker, noted for his snappy attire. In 1935, a panel of tailors voted him the best-dressed man in the country. William and his buddies once rode a coach-and-four 206 miles from Manhattan to Newport, RI, just to play polo. The trip, taken at a gallop, required 21 changes of horses. Here's the story, reported decades later, in a 1935 issue of Time Magazine: www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,748315,00.html

Reginald Claypoole Vanderbilt, (1880-1925) Gloria Vanderbilt's father.  Reggie Vanderbilt, as he was popularly known, was the youngest son of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt and wife Alice.  He attended Yale, but didn't graduate.   Reggie went through most all of the millions of his father's inheritance from high living, automobile collecting, horses, gambling and drinking.  All well documented in diaries and the press,and even later in a television docu-drama on Little Gloria, and the famous custody case of 1934.  Reggie was founder or president of many equestrian organizations. NYTimes reported he died of throat infection, although popularly reported to have died from complications from liver failure from alcohol consumption, and lifestyle.

When the LOC uploads images with "no rights reserved", they need to be tagged as PUBLIC DOMAIN. This would help clarify the rights status.

In contrast to a photographer or other rights holder, the Library of Congress has no authority to waive copyright protection or to transfer or license rights. There may be no evidence of a rights holder, but that is not the same thing as stating affirmatively that something is in the public domain. We needed to offer an observation, not an active assertion, which is why we don' t simply use the "public domain" designation. That is why the Additional information about the images from the Library of Congress says "No known copyright restrictions." Selecting the link takes you to the page on the Library of Congress site that goes into more detail about what we mean by "no known copyright restrictions": www.loc.gov/rr/print/195_copr.html#noknown

Is that a stone under the seat?

This is amazing: King Edward's Chair, sometimes known as St Edward's Chair or The Coronation Chair, is the throne on which the British monarch sits for the coronation. It was commissioned in 1296 by King Edward I to contain the coronation stone of Scotland ‚Äî known as the Stone of Scone ‚Äî which he had captured from the Scots who had kept it at Scone Abbey. The chair was named after England's only canonized king, Edward the Confessor, and was kept in his shrine of St Edward's Chapel at Westminster Abbey. This article can be found at: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_Edward's_Chair

Yes, amazing. Nowadays, the Stone of Scone is no longer there, having been repatriated to Scotland: www.royal.gov.uk/output/page2015.asp The rest of the chair can be seen in Westminster Abbey, and will surely feature during the next Coronation.
Returned to Scotland in 1996. And if you think it will be returned to England for the next Coronation ... hmm...
